The over-reliance on fossil fuels has led to significant environmental and climatic challenges, emphasizing the urgent need for sustainable energy alternatives. Biodiesel, which is traditionally produced through the transesterification of vegetable oils and animal fats, provides a low-carbon alternative to fossil fuels. However, for catalytic systems, the efficiency of biodiesel synthesis is significantly dependent on the nature of the catalysts used. Conventional homogeneous catalysts, although effective, face challenges such as high energy consumption, soap formation, non-recoverability, and corrosion issues. In contrast, heterogeneous catalysts, especially those derived from biogenic waste, offer cost, reusability, and environmental impact advantages. This review provides a comprehensive examination of the synthesis methods and performance of heterogeneous catalysts derived from waste materials for biodiesel production, representing an elucidation of the role of synthesis methods on the properties of these catalysts. Understanding this relationship is important for optimizing biodiesel production efficiency as global efforts intensify to transition away from fossil fuels. This review analyzes the properties of these catalysts, such as surface area, pore structure, morphology, metal dispersion, chemical composition, and thermal stability, using fit-for-purpose characterization techniques. By focusing on the synthesis-property-performance nexus, this review highlights the importance of selecting and optimizing synthesis methods to achieve high-performance catalysts for efficient biodiesel production. The review also addresses challenges in heterogeneous catalyst synthesis, providing a balanced perspective on the current state of the art. Importantly, this work establishes a new framework for understanding and optimizing bio-derived catalyst synthesis, paving the way for more efficient and sustainable biodiesel production methods. This review contributes new knowledge to the field of renewable energy, aligning with global sustainability goals. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biodiesel synthesis Heterogeneous catalysts Bio-derived precursors Transesterification Catalyst synthesis methods Renewable energy Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The increasing global population and high standards of living have led to a significant increase in global energy consumption [1]. In 2020, the global total primary energy consumption (TPEC) was approximately 642 EJ, and it is projected to increase to 879 EJ by 2050 [2]. Presently, the transportation sector, which is a major driver of the global economy, is heavily dependent on non-renewable fossil fuels [3]. Currently, fossil fuels account for 80 % of total primary energy consumption, with 24 % consumed by the transportation sector, with road transportation taking the largest share as shown in Fig. 1 [4]. The energy consumption in the transportation sector is anticipated to grow at an average rate of 1.1 % per year from 2020 in excessive reliance on non-renewable petroleum-based fuels to satisfy global energy demands [5]. This over-reliance on fossil-sourced fuels will exacerbate well-reported challenges of greenhouse gas emissions [6], acid rain [7], global warming [8], ecological imbalances [9], and the deletion of global fossil fuel reserves [10]. The finite nature of fossil fuels and the negative consequences associated with their excessive consumption have motivated researchers to consider alternative energy sources [1]. Among these alternatives, biofuels derived from renewable resources, such as municipal waste, plants, agricultural and forestry residues, have shown promise [11]. These biofuels are not only environmentally benign but also sustainable. In recent times, biofuels like biodiesel have garnered substantial interest from the scientific community due to their potential to serve as a cleaner substitute for fossil fuels [1,12]. Biodiesel is increasingly recognized as a promising and sustainable substitute for conventional diesel fuel. It has several advantages, such as being biodegradable, renewable, non-toxic, and environmentally friendly [13,14]. Additionally, it serves as an effective solvent, removing residue accumulated in the combustion chamber by petroleum-based diesel and ensuring optimal engine performance [15]. Another advantage of biodiesel is its compatibility with petroleum-based diesel. It can be blended with petroleum-based diesel in various ratios, as they share similar chemical properties, and can be utilized in existing diesel engines without requiring modifications [16]. This enables the widespread adoption of biodiesel using the existing infrastructure for petroleum-based diesel distribution [17]. Although there are several synthesis pathways available for producing biodiesel, including pyrolysis, supercritical fluid method, microemulsification, membrane process, reactive distillation, and ultrasound process, the transesterification of oils and fats is the most prevalent method [18]. This process involves the reaction of triglyceride, which is found in oils or fats, with a suitable alcohol, in the presence of a catalyst, to form fatty acid alkyl esters (FAAE), also known as biodiesel (Fig. 2 ) [19]. While other alcohols such as ethanol can be used, the vast majority of studies in the literature have utilized methanol to yield biodiesel in the form of fatty acid methyl esters (FAME). During this procedure, glycerol is separated from the biodiesel and refined before being stored and used (Fig. 3 ). Glycerol has different industrial applications. It is extensively utilized in pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, food additives, and biopolymer synthesis as well as a precursor for value-added chemicals such as propylene glycol, alkyd resin, epichlorohydrin, polyhydroxyalkanoates, and glycerol carbonate, thereby enhancing the economic viability and sustainability of biodiesel production [20]. Fig. 3 illustrates the transesterification process using acid and alkaline catalysts, tailored to the nature of the oil feedstock to minimize unwanted saponification and hydrolysis reactions. However, it is important to recognize that acid-catalyzed processes generally operate at a slower rate compared to those using alkaline catalysts. To improve the sustainability of these processes, enzymes have been investigated as potential catalysts for transesterification. Despite their promise, enzyme-catalyzed transesterification reactions are notably slower, and the high cost of enzymes further limits their commercial viability. Although the cost of feedstock is a dominant factor, accounting for over 80 % of biodiesel production cost [22], the type of catalyst employed is equally important, as it is the key factor that facilitates the transesterification reaction to completion [23]. Catalysts for biodiesel synthesis are categorized into conventional and unconventional. While conventional catalysts are chemical catalysts derived from inorganic resources or biological catalysts which are mainly enzymes, unconventional catalysts are derived from biogenic waste resources [23,24]. Catalysts are further classified as homogeneous or heterogeneous depending on whether they exist in the same phase as the reactants or in a different phase, respectively. Homogeneous catalysts were the first to be utilized for in-situ transesterification and examples include both acid catalysts such as HCl and H2SO4 and alkaline catalysts including KOH and NaOH [25,26]. The conventional homogeneous catalysts used in biodiesel production processes are limited by their selectivity for feedstocks based on fatty acid content, sensitivity to moisture content, non-recoverability, and the formation of soap, which ultimately results in a lower yield of biodiesel [17]. Additionally, separation issues and corrosion potentials increase the cost of production and have negative impacts on the environment [27]. Considering these limitations, the utilization of heterogeneous catalysts, typically in the solid state is essential due to their benign nature with such catalysts existing in a separate phase from the reactants and are often solid. There are three main types of heterogeneous catalysts used in biodiesel production: basic, acidic, and bifunctional. Examples of basic catalysts include metal oxides, mixed oxides, and hydrotalcite, while transition metal oxides, ion exchange resin, and zeolites are commonly used for acidic reactions [28]. Furthermore, bifunctional catalysts include CaO-Fe2O3/AC [29], anthill-eggshell-Ni-Co [30] etc. Research in heterogeneously catalyzed biodiesel production has been receiving a lot of attention in recent years. This is reflected in the publication trend of biodiesel production using heterogeneous catalysts, with an evident significant increase in recent years (Fig. 4 ). This trend highlights the growing importance of heterogeneous catalysts in the context of biodiesel production. According to several literature sources [31–33], the role of the synthesis technique on the overall properties of waste-derived catalysts is crucial to enhancing the biodiesel yield. Also, Changmai et al. [34] and Kosuru et al. [35] reported a sharp increase in studies exploring the art and science of catalysis, especially with the emergence of biomass-derived, nano, and bifunctional catalysts in the recent decade. Catalyst preparation methods such as physical/solid mixing [36], direct calcination [37], calcination-hydration-dehydration [38], wet impregnation [39], co-precipitation [40], and sol-gel [41] can influence the physicochemical properties of the catalyst [32]. These properties are measured using various characterization techniques which provide valuable insights into the catalyst's suitability and performance in the biodiesel production processes. Although several reviews have discussed various types of biodiesel catalysts, focusing on preparation conditions and precursor types, certain limitations and gaps have been observed. For instance, Ghosh et al. [18] reviewed the current state and prospects of heterogeneous catalytic transesterification for biodiesel synthesis from waste cooking oil. The study focused on the efficiency, reusability, and life cycle assessment of heterogeneous catalysts utilized in biodiesel synthesis from waste cooking oil. In another review, the impact of heterogeneous catalysts on biodiesel production was reviewed with a focus on evaluating various types of heterogeneous catalysts and their effects on biodiesel yield, particularly when using waste materials as precursors [42]. Ismaeel et al. [21] also reviewed advancements in catalysts for biodiesel production, emphasizing the significance of catalyst basicity and acidity in transesterification and esterification processes. Notably, these previous works did not consider the role and importance of synthesis methods in shaping the physicochemical characteristics and catalytic properties of heterogeneous catalysts made from waste-derived precursors. This represents a major gap in the literature, as synthesis methods can greatly influence catalyst properties such as surface area, pore structure, thermal stability, and reusability. These factors are crucial for catalytic performance and, consequently, for effective biodiesel production [31]. Therefore, this review aims to address this gap by conducting a thorough examination of the various synthesis methods and their influence on the properties and catalytic performance of waste-derived heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production. This review will further enhance the understanding of novel synthesis methods that may optimize catalyst properties for improved biodiesel production. By emphasizing waste-derived precursors, it aligns with sustainable and circular economy practices, potentially leading to higher productivity, reduced costs, and energy savings in biodiesel synthesis. A comprehensive overview of the current state of waste-derived heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production is provided, serving as a valuable reference for researchers and industry professionals. The review discusses key preparation techniques, including physical/solid mixing, calcination, wet impregnation, and sol-gel methods, and examines their impact on crucial factors such as crystallite size, thermal stability, morphology, metal dispersion, and chemical composition. The insights presented contribute significantly to the field of sustainable catalysis for biodiesel production, highlighting the importance of innovative synthesis methods in enhancing catalyst performance and promoting environmentally friendly practices. 2 Catalysts used for biodiesel production 2.1 Homogeneous catalysts Homogeneous catalysts, including acid and alkaline catalysts, have been used to catalyze the transesterification of triglycerides to produce biodiesel. These catalysts are conventional and widely used for biodiesel production due to their lower required concentration and higher reaction rates [43]. Their advantages include high activity, short reaction times, and low cost. However, because they exist in the same phase as the reactants and products, they pose an inherent difficulty in separation from the product, in addition to the generation of biodiesel wash water whose disposal has environmental implications. Furthermore, they are sensitive to the free fatty acid (FFA) content and the water content of the oil [44]. Homogeneous catalysts can be either basic or acidic, with each leveraging distinct reaction mechanisms or pathways. 2.1.1 Homogeneous basic catalysts Homogeneous basic catalysts include alkali metal hydroxides such as NaOH and KOH, and alkali metal alkoxides such as CH3ONa and CH3OK. Hamed et al. [45] compared the role of NaOH and KOH in catalyzing the transesterification of waste cooking oil. Both catalysts were evaluated at different weight percentages (ranging from 0.3 to 1.0 wt. %) at varying reaction temperatures (50 – 80 °C). At the identified optimum operating conditions of 60 °C reaction temperature, 3 h reaction time, and 0.4 wt. % catalyst concentration of KOH, a higher yield of 97.76 % was obtained with KOH compared to the 94.4 % obtained with NaOH. They also observed less soap formation with KOH. In a similar study, Belkhanchi et al. [46] optimized the transesterification reaction conditions for biodiesel production from a mixture of frying oils (soybean, sunflower, canola) using NaOH or KOH as a catalyst, with their mass ratio ranging between 0.5 % and 2 %. They obtained a maximum biodiesel yield of 98.1 % with a 1 % mass of KOH, compared to 92.8 % with a 0.5 % mass of NaOH. In another study, Radjarejesri et al. [47] addressed the challenge of volatile organic compounds associated with the use of homogeneous catalysts in transesterification reactions. They synthesized biodiesel from palm oil with a 94.16 % yield using ultrasonic-assisted transesterification and a KOH catalyst, with a reaction time of 65 min, a temperature of 60 °C, a methanol-oil ratio of 7:1, and a catalyst loading of 1 wt. %. To improve the competitiveness of the biodiesel production chain, metal glyceroxide homogeneous catalysts have also been employed for biodiesel production. For example, Santos et al. [43] achieved a biodiesel yield exceeding 98 % by employing sodium glyceroxide as a catalyst in the transesterification of soy oil. The sodium glyceroxide was synthesized by reacting sodium hydroxide in ethanol with glycerol. The catalyst was then dissolved in methanol, producing a homogeneous solution. The optimal conditions for this process were identified as a methanol-oil ratio of 12:1, a catalyst loading of 2 wt. %, a reaction temperature of 50 °C, and a reaction duration of 60 min. Although alkali catalysts face challenges that must be overcome for wider industrial use, significant advancements have been made in discovering new alkali catalysts and designing reactors to enhance their application. Also, while alkali metal alkoxides have been applied to address the water and soap formation encountered with the use of alkali metal catalysts, they pose safety and cost concerns. Hence, metal glyceroxide alkaline catalysts offer the potential to address some of the challenges associated with other homogeneous alkaline catalysts. 2.1.2 Homogeneous acid catalysts Homogeneous acid catalysts are reported as good alternatives to address the soap formation issues encountered with the use of alkali catalysts. These catalysts are particularly suitable for oils with FFA greater than 1 % [48] and eliminate the need for oil pretreatment as they facilitate both esterification and transesterification reactions [49]. Acid catalysts have the advantage of being used with a wide range of feedstock oils, including non-edible and waste cooking oils, which usually have higher FFA content. Several studies have reported the use of acid-based homogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production from a variety of feedstocks. Lawer-Yolar et al. [50] reported the optimal synthesis of biodiesel from tall oil fatty acid using sulfuric acid as a catalyst. They compared sulfuric acid, a homogeneous catalyst, with Amberlyst® BD20, a heterogeneous catalyst, and found that sulfuric acid produced a higher biodiesel yield of 96.76 %. However, it was not reusable. Conversely, Amberlyst® BD20 had a lower yield of 90.24 % but was reusable. The optimum reaction conditions for the homogeneous catalysis were a methanol molar ratio of 15:1, a temperature of 55 °C, a catalyst concentration of 0.5 wt. %, and a reaction time of 60 min. To reduce the reliance on unsustainable Lewis-acid catalysts made from rare transition metals, research suggests using highly-active salen-based catalysts. These catalysts are effective and pose fewer concerns about impurities. For example, Melchiorre et al. [51] produced biodiesel from waste cooking oil using an iron(III) salen-based homogeneous catalyst with residual catalyst concentration found to be in the range of 10–14 ppm. At an optimized reaction temperature of 180 °C, a reaction time of 2 h, a methanol-oil ratio of 20:1, and a catalyst loading of 0.1 wt. %, they obtained biodiesel yields greater than 90 %. In a similar study, Langellotti et al. [49] improved the salen-based catalyst used by Melchiorre et al. [51], redesigning its structure by replacing the cyclohexanediamine portion with o-phenylenediamine to preserve catalytic activity while reducing steric hindrance. They achieved a maximum biodiesel yield of 98 % with a 20:1 methanol-oil ratio, a reaction temperature of 160 °C, a reaction time of 120 min, and a catalyst loading of 0.1 wt. %. In another study that focused on the separation of homogeneous catalysts from biodiesel, Vlnieska et al. [52] utilized oligocat, made of oligoesters as a pseudo-homogeneous acid catalyst, which remains in a homogeneous phase during the reaction. This pseudo-homogeneous acid catalyst was observed to become viscous after the reaction, enabling easy separation from the biodiesel product. They produced biodiesel from tallow fat and soybean oil, achieving over 97.6 % yield with a 25:1 methanol-oil ratio, a 90 °C reaction temperature, a reaction time of 36 h, and a catalyst loading of 15 %. Unlike other homogeneous catalysts, this catalyst was reusable, with a 96.7 % yield after the third use. Although acid catalysts allow for the use of a broader range of oil feedstocks, including those with high free fatty acid (FFA) content for biodiesel production, they are reported to have slower reaction rates compared to alkaline catalysts [23]. Consequently, they are currently employed together with alkaline catalysts in a two-step process, with the acid facilitating esterification and the alkaline catalyst facilitating transesterification [31]. However, this approach could come at a higher cost. The development of homogeneous acid catalysts with low concentrations in the biodiesel product and the development of pseudo-homogeneous catalysts, which allow for the reusability of homogeneous catalysts, hold significant promise in biodiesel catalysis. Table 1 summarizes homogeneous catalysts used for biodiesel production as reviewed in this section. 2.2 Heterogeneous catalysts Research in biodiesel production via transesterification is now increasingly exploring the use of heterogeneous catalysis compared to homogeneous catalysis. Although homogeneous catalysts enable rapid reactions, their disadvantages, such as unfavorable environmental impact, poor reusability, and toxicity, significantly outweigh their benefits [53]. A heterogeneous biodiesel catalyst, on the other hand, is associated with reduced energy requirement and water consumption, in addition to the fact that they are generally eco-friendly and can be reused due to their ease of separation from the final product, thus making the process economical [54]. In heterogeneous catalysis, the reaction materials and catalysts are in two different phases with the catalyst typically in solid form. Due to the different phases in which it acts, catalyst recovery from the reaction mixture is simplified, and the catalysts can be reused for several cycles which positively impacts the cost of the process [42]. Furthermore, heterogeneous solid catalysts offer the flexibility of continuous biodiesel production in fixed-bed reactors, making higher production possible on an industrial scale [23]. Heterogeneous catalysts can be classified as solid acid, base, bifunctional, and waste-derived and these will be discussed in the following sections. 2.2.1 Heterogeneous acid catalysts Heterogeneous acid catalysts can be used to facilitate biodiesel production through esterification and transesterification, effectively substituting for homogeneous acid catalysts. The presence of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on these solid catalysts makes them more valuable industrially compared to homogeneous acid catalysts [23]. Heterogeneous acid catalysts can overcome the significant issues of vessel corrosion and toxicity commonly encountered with homogeneous acid catalysts. They are also not sensitive to high free fatty acid and water content in oil feedstock, enabling the use of low-quality, inexpensive feedstocks without the need for acid pretreatment in biodiesel production [55]. Although heterogeneous acid catalysts show promise under moderate reaction conditions, their rates are typically lower, because of low accessibility of active sites, compared to reaction rates achieved when heterogeneous base catalysts are used. Thus, the use of these catalysts necessitates higher catalyst loading, high temperatures, and longer reaction times [56]. Recently, different types of heterogeneous acid catalysts have been used in esterification and transesterification processes. These include metal oxides, mixed metal oxides, sulfated metal oxides, sulfonated carbon materials, heteropoly acids, and zeolites [57]. An optimally functional heterogeneous acid catalyst should possess a large pore size, a high density of strong acid sites, and hydrophobic properties [23]. Heteropoly acids (HPAs) are a class of heterogeneous solid catalysts that have been used for biodiesel production. They consist of acidic hydrogen-oxygen-addenda atoms such as molybdenum (Mo), vanadium (V), tungsten (W), and heteroatoms such as phosphorus (P), silicon (Si), and arsenic (As). These catalysts possess high oxidizing ability, thermal stability, and acidity. For example, Esmi et al. [58] synthesized and characterized three solid HPA catalysts namely: mesoporous aluminophosphate-supported 12-tungstophosphoric heteropoly acid (HPW/MAP), mesoporous aluminosilicate-supported 12-tungstophosphoric heteropoly acid (HPW/MAS), and gamma alumina-supported 12-tungstophosphoric heteropoly acid (HPW/γ-Al2O3) for biodiesel production (Fig. 5 ). HPW/MAP and HPW/MAS were prepared using sol-gel and hydrothermal methods, respectively. The performance of the catalysts was evaluated through alcoholysis of unrefined green seed canola oil. HPW/MAS exhibited the highest biodiesel yield at 82.3 % at optimal conditions of 3 wt. % catalyst, a 20:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio, at 200 °C and 4 MPa for 7 h. Reusability tests showed that HPW/MAS maintained 80 % activity after five cycles. In another study, Ghasemzadeh et al. [59] investigated the performance of a magnetically recoverable HPA-based catalyst – rubber-Fe3O4@SiO2@H3PMo12O40 developed by impregnation of phosphomolybdic acid (PMA) for use in biodiesel production. Using response surface methodology (RSM), the performance of the catalyst was evaluated, and the results showed that the optimum values for catalyst dosage, reaction time, molar ratio of methanol-to-oil, and reaction temperature were 3 wt. %, 3 h, 12:1 and 69 °C respectively. The resulting yield of biodiesel was observed to be greater than 85 % for four consecutive runs. Similarly, Ghasemzadeh et al. [60] synthesized a new magnetically recoverable catalyst (cotton/Fe3O4@SiO2@H3PW12O40) based on cotton waste and investigated its application in the production of biodiesel. The performance of the catalyst was also evaluated and optimized using RSM. The optimum conditions were reported as 3 wt. %, 3.5 h, 12:1, and 70 °C, for catalyst dosage, reaction time, methanol-to-oil molar ratio, and the reaction temperature, respectively for a production yield higher than 90 % for three consecutive runs. Among various solid acid catalysts used in biodiesel production, many studies have highlighted the application of sulfonic acid catalysts, particularly sulfonated cross-linked polystyrene and sulfated metal oxides, and sulfated zirconia, due to their high catalytic activity. For instance, Soltani et al. [61] synthesized sugar-containing mesoporous ZnO-TiO2 hollow spheres using a high-pressure reactor and partial carbonization of glucose as a templating agent. The resulting mesoporous catalyst was functionalized using chlorosulfonic acid, leading to the attachment of -SO3H functional groups to the mesoporous walls. The catalytic activity was tested through transesterification of waste edible palm oil. Under optimal conditions, (1 wt. % catalyst, 6:1 methanol-oil molar ratio, 100 °C reaction temperature, and 75 min reaction time), the fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) yield reached 96.1 %. Reusability experiments demonstrated high activity retention after 10 cycles with minimal FAME yield reduction. In another study, Tang et al. [62] investigated the use of biomass waste-derived acid catalysts for biodiesel production by comparing the catalytic performance of activated carbon (AC) synthesized from papaya seed, empty fruit bunch, and corncob. The AC was efficiently sulfonated using the arylation of 4-benzene-diazonium sulfonate, resulting in high porosity with surface areas ranging from 639.68 to 972.66 m²/g. The corncob-derived sulfonated AC catalyst exhibited the highest performance, achieving an FAME yield of 72.09 % and an FFA conversion of 93.49 % under optimal conditions. Reusability tests indicated that this catalyst maintained high FAME yields during the first two reaction cycles. More recent studies have highlighted the use of sulfated oxide-based catalysts for biodiesel production. For example, Yusuf et al. [63] prepared β-zeolite-zinc oxide and sulfated-zinc oxide supported on β-zeolite (ZnO-β-zeolite and SO4 2–/ZnO-β-zeolite, respectively) and investigated their catalytic performance in the production of biodiesel using waste cooking oil (WCO). The results of their investigation revealed that the highest WCO conversion of 96.9 % was obtained using the SO42–/ZnO-β-zeolite catalyst under an optimum reaction condition of 3.0 wt % catalyst loading, 200 °C reaction temperature, and 15:1 molar ratio of methanol-to-oil in an 8 h reaction time. The stability and reusability of the catalysts were evaluated, and it was found that the SO42–/ZnO-β-zeolite catalyst exhibited good stability, maintaining a biodiesel yield above 80 % after three cycles. In another study, Karimi and Saidi, [64] prepared a sulfated mordenite catalyst by using the impregnation method coupled with modification via sulfation. This novel hydrophobic sulfated mordenite catalyst was applied for biodiesel production from neem seed-derived oil (NSDO) by electrochemical method. The highest yield of the process was obtained as 85 % with operating conditions of 6 wt. % of the catalyst, an electric potential of 10 V, a MeOH/NSDO molar ratio of 10:1, and a reaction time of 1 h. The catalyst displayed remarkable performance and reusability, with a mere 15 % decrease in the reaction yield after five consecutive cycles. Table 2 summarizes some studies that deployed solid acid catalysts for biodiesel production. These studies show that cation-exchange resins, heteropoly acids, sulfonated, and sulfated catalysts show impressive catalytic activity and durability across a range of feedstocks and reaction conditions. Sulfonation is typically used to enhance acidity, which is important for activating esterification reactions by facilitating electrophile generation. While initial yields are high, some studies reported a decline in catalytic activity over repeated cycles, indicating the importance of catalyst stability and potential challenges in maintaining high yields over extended usage [63]. Future research should focus on optimizing catalyst preparation techniques for improved catalyst efficiency and stability over multiple cycles. Additionally, exploring the scalability of solid acid catalysts for biodiesel production and assessing the economic viability of integrating these catalysts into industrial settings will be essential for advancing their practical application. 2.2.2 Heterogeneous basic catalyst A heterogeneous basic catalyst is designed to address challenges like saponification, which reduces FAME yield by impeding glycerol separation from the methyl ester layer, a limitation observed with homogeneous base catalysts. Additionally, these catalysts exhibit enhanced catalytic efficiency under milder reaction conditions [56]. Basic solid catalysts are generally more advantageous than solid acid catalysts because of their higher reaction rates compared to heterogeneous acid catalysts [38]. Metal oxides are commonly used as the primary components of heterogeneous basic catalysts for the transesterification process to produce biodiesel. They possess inherent traits such as thermal and mechanical stability, along with high specific surface area and large pore size and volume. The most common of them include calcium oxide (CaO), magnesium oxide (MgO), and barium oxide (BaO) [72]. The performance of basic heterogeneous catalysts such as CaO, MgO, ZnO, and Ba(OH)2, was investigated by Miyuranga et al. [73]. Their findings revealed that Ba(OH)2 achieved the highest biodiesel yield of 92 %, followed by CaO with 84 wt. %, and then MgO and ZnO performed relatively poorly with yields of 40 % and 30 % respectively. Although all the catalysts were reusable, only Ba(OH)2 and CaO maintained significant yields up to the third cycle. In a similar study, Al-Abbasi et al. [74] explored the production of biodiesel from sunflower oil using barium oxide (BaO) nanoparticles synthesized via one-pot sol-gel reactions as a catalyst. The highest biodiesel yield of 78.38 % was achieved with a catalyst concentration of 4.7 wt. % at a temperature of 70 °C and a 1:20 oil-to-methanol molar ratio. In recent times, extensive research has been conducted to develop solid basic catalysts derived from various agricultural and industrial wastes. Carbon-based solid catalysts are becoming increasingly popular for biodiesel production due to their low cost and availability [23]. For instance, Mengistu and Reshad, [72], investigated the synthesis of a basic heterogeneous catalyst from a mixture of waste animal teeth and bone through a calcination method. The catalyst was utilized for biodiesel production from castor seed oil. The purity of the produced biodiesel, measured in terms of its FAME content, was 92.6 % which was obtained with a catalyst loading of 5 wt. %, a methanol-to-oil molar ratio of 9:1 at a reaction temperature of 60 °C for 3 h. In another study, Kedir et al. [75] prepared a snail shell-based CaO catalyst supported by ZnO and TiO2 for converting waste cooking palm oil into biodiesel through transesterification. They employed sol-gel and wet-impregnation techniques to synthesize ZnO and the catalyst, respectively. The study found that the CaO catalyst resulted in an 80 % yield of biodiesel from waste cooking oil. Modification of the CaO catalyst with ZnO and TiO2 increased the biodiesel yield to 90 % and 95 %, respectively. The optimal conditions for achieving the highest biodiesel yield with the synthesized catalysts were determined to be a 3 wt. % catalyst weight, a temperature of 65 °C, a methanol-to-oil ratio of 6:1, and a reaction time of 3 h. In a similar report, Okoduwa et al. [17] synthesized a biobased mixed metal oxide catalyst containing CaO, K2O, SiO2, and NiO from waste marble tiles and cow horn through sequential calcination and wet impregnation for the synthesis of biodiesel from waste cooking oil. Using RSM and artificial neural networks (ANN), the authors reported that an optimum biodiesel yield of 98 % was attainable at a reaction time of 119.92 min, a catalyst concentration of 5.12 wt. %, a reaction temperature of 74.86 °C, and methanol-to-oil ratio of 11.43:1. The catalyst was reusable for up to seven cycles while retaining significant catalytic activity. In another study, Alsaiari et al. [76], investigated the efficacy of a green catalyst derived from waste camel bone for producing biodiesel from date seed oil, a valuable non-edible resource. Their findings showed that the camel bone-derived catalyst, composed mainly of hydroxyapatite facilitated an 89 % biodiesel yield. This catalyst maintained its activity over multiple cycles without significant degradation. The optimal reaction parameters were determined to be a temperature of 75 °C, a reaction time of 180 min, an ethanol-to-oil molar ratio of 7:1, and a catalyst loading of 4 wt. %, resulting in a maximum biodiesel yield of 89 %. Using waste from the sugar industry, Bedir and Doğan, [77] produced a solid basic catalyst for the transesterification of sunflower oil to produce biodiesel. Optimum reaction conditions were also determined to be at 5 wt. % catalyst amount and 15:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio at 60 °C for 2 h, the highest biodiesel yield of 87.64 % was obtained. Reusability tests showed that the biodiesel yield was 80 % after three reaction cycles. In a different report, Mansoorsamaei et al. [78] investigated the production of biodiesel through the transesterification of waste cooking oil with methanol. To facilitate the reaction, a novel heterogeneous catalyst, derived from waste banana peels and composed of biochar-Fe2O3/Fe2K6O5, was employed. The results indicated that optimal conditions for achieving a biodiesel yield of 88.83 % were a methanol-to-oil molar ratio of 7:1 and a catalyst concentration of 4 wt. % for a reaction time of 3 h at 60 °C. The reviewed studies collectively highlight significant progress in the field of biodiesel production using waste-derived heterogeneous catalysts. These catalysts, including metal oxides like CaO and BaO, exhibit better catalytic efficiency and stability under mild reaction conditions compared to their homogeneous counterparts. The research reviewed in this section suggests that while metal oxides possess desirable qualities such as thermal stability and extensive surface areas, optimization of their properties is necessary to ensure consistently high yields across multiple cycles. Additionally, the use of waste-derived materials like animal bones and industrial byproducts has been shown to produce cost-effective and environmentally friendly catalysts. These advancements highlight the potential for incorporating heterogeneous basic catalysts into industrial biodiesel production, stressing the need for further investigation into catalyst preparation methods and scalability. Table 3 provides a summary of some heterogeneous basic catalysts, and the yield of biodiesel obtained at various reaction conditions. 2.2.3 Heterogeneous bifunctional catalyst Bifunctional catalysts, featuring both acidic and basic active sites, are regarded as effective for the esterification and transesterification of low-quality raw oils [82]. Oils with high FFA content (> 1 wt. %) need an acid catalyst to convert the FFA through esterification before transesterification can proceed. For efficient biodiesel production from such oils, a heterogeneous catalytic system featuring both acidic and basic sites is desirable to perform both esterification and transesterification. Several of these bifunctional catalysts have been reported for use in biodiesel production. For example, Jamil et al. [83] synthesized a carbon-based heterogeneous bi-functional catalyst. The catalyst was prepared from post-extraction date seed powder which was carbonized in an inert atmosphere at 400 °C for 5 h to obtain carbon material. The resulting carbon material was modified using alkaline earth metal oxide through wet impregnation and assessed its suitability for transesterification reaction to produce biodiesel using oils from different sources (palm oil, date seed oil, waste cooking oil, and coconut oil). The basic sites were identified via XRD as being mainly consisting of MgO, CaO, SrO and BaO while the acidic sites are identified as Bronsted and Lewis type. The results of transesterification reaction revealed that the optimized yield of biodiesel was 94.27 % at the optimum reaction conditions of 65 °C, 90 min, methanol-to-oil molar ratio of 15, and catalyst loading of 4 wt. %. Furthermore, the reusability of the synthesized heterogeneous catalyst was assessed, and the findings revealed that the catalyst was highly active even after six cycles. In a different study, Amenaghawon et al. [33] assessed the potential of a composite bio-based heterogeneous catalyst derived from fused crab shells and plantain peels for the transesterification of waste cooking oil. Powdered crab shells and plantain peel were calcined at 900 °C for 4 h and 500 °C for 3 h respectively and then doped with aluminum using the wet impregnation method. The catalyst exhibited bifunctional properties due to the presence of basic oxides (calcium and potassium) and acidic oxides (silicon and iron). Its high surface area (260.35 m2/g) and pore volume (0.65 cm3/g) contributed to an optimal biodiesel yield of 93 % under reaction conditions of 60 °C, 5 wt. % catalyst loading, 149.94 min reaction time, and a methanol-to-oil ratio of 13.03:1. The catalyst demonstrated strong stability, maintaining biodiesel yields above 80 % after six cycles of reuse. Similarly, Amenaghawon et al. [12] investigated biodiesel production from a ternary feedstock blend consisting of waste cooking oil, waste palm oil, and waste animal fat (65.46 wt. %, 18.56 wt. %, and 15.98 wt. %, respectively) using a composite heterogeneous catalyst derived from calcined plantain peduncle and waste marble tiles. The catalyst was comprised of Ca (47.80 %), K (11.06 %), Mg (4.11 %), and Al (2.31 %). Their study reported an optimal biodiesel yield of 98.31 % at a reaction temperature of 61 °C, 2 wt. % catalyst concentration, 149.98 min reaction time, and a methanol-to-oil ratio of 6.01:1. The catalyst also exhibited reasonable stability, as confirmed through reusability tests conducted over six cycles. Furthermore, Ibrahim et al. [29] synthesized a magnetic bifunctional nanocatalyst, CaO-Fe2O3/AC, supported on activated carbon for waste cooking oil transesterification. The optimized catalyst, CaO (10 %)- Fe2O3(10 %)/AC, exhibited significant acidic and basic desorption capacities of 18,532 μmol/g and 2653 μmol/g, respectively, resulting in a maximum biodiesel yield of 98.3 % under the conditions of 3 wt. % catalyst loading, an 18:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio, and a reaction temperature of 65 °C for 3 h. Reusability studies revealed a high catalytic stability, with biodiesel yield exceeding 80 % for at least six consecutive cycles. Bekele et al. [84] developed bifunctional catalysts for synthesizing waste frying oil methyl ester (WFOME), utilizing zirconia (ZrO2) as a promoter. They used coffee husk (CH) alone and a mixture of CH and Eragrostis tef straw (TS) as biomass precursors. The bifunctional catalysts were prepared using zirconia-promoted CH ash catalysts via precipitation followed by impregnation (Bic-PP) and in situ precipitation–impregnation (Bic-Dm). The report revealed the presence of K2Ca(CO3)2, K2CO3, and K2O which contributed to the alkalinity strength of the catalyst while the bifunctional catalyst also included the Lewis acid site source tetragonal zirconia (t-ZrO2) crystal in their structure. The optimum WFOME yields were 92.69 % and 93.05 % for Bic-Dm, and Bic-PP, respectively, under reaction conditions of 65 °C, 1 h reaction time, and a methanol-to-WFO molar ratio of 15:1, using 7 wt. % catalysts. The studies reviewed have demonstrated that different catalyst types, including carbon-based variants, functionalized with alkaline earth metal oxides and composite biobased catalysts synthesized from waste materials, can achieve high biodiesel yields under optimal conditions. Reusability tests have also shown that bifunctional catalysts maintain exceptional catalytic activity over multiple reaction cycles, suggesting potential industrial applications. The utilization of eco-friendly waste materials as precursors coupled with innovative synthesis processes enhances the efficiency, stability, and economic viability of these catalysts. This further underscores the potential of bifunctional catalysts to improve biodiesel production processes while enhancing sustainability and reducing costs. Table 4 provides a summary of some bifunctional catalysts, and the yield of biodiesel obtained at various reaction conditions. 2.3 Enzymatic catalysts Enzymes are highly specific biomolecular catalysts that have been employed in biodiesel production in recent years. These biocatalysts overcome the underlying issues that accompany the use of alkali or acid catalysts in conventional chemical processes, such as high water content and free fatty acid content present in the oil or fat feedstocks. Since enzymatic reactions typically occur at moderate pH and temperatures, they require low energy consumption. Also, with enzymatic catalysts, the products can easily be separated and purified, simplifying the production process [23]. Several researchers have exploited the aforementioned qualities of enzymatic catalysts in biodiesel production with lipases and immobilized lipases receiving significant attention. For example, due to the insensitivity of enzyme-catalysts to FFA, Farobie et al. [85] produced biodiesel from crude palm oil (CPO) using a Versa Transform 2.0 lipase catalyst. The CPO, a feedstock with high FFA content, was used at different FFA levels. They reported a biodiesel yield of up to 97.91 % at 40 °C, 19.33 % FFA content, and methanol-to-CPO molar ratio of 7:1 for 40 h. Free enzymes are limited in their sensitivity to reaction media and stability in operations. Immobilization techniques, which involve localizing enzymes using solid supports, address some of these challenges by improving the biocatalyst recovery, enzyme activity, specificity, and selectivity [86,87]. Thus, Parandi et al. [88] reported a biodiesel yield of 96 % at a reaction temperature of 40 °C, 30 h reaction time, 1 g biocatalyst dosage, and 4:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio when Candida antarctica lipase B (CALB) immobilized on silica-coated Fe3O4 was used for the transesterification of waste cooking oil. They observed an increased stability of the immobilized enzyme compared to the free-state enzyme. In a similar study, Parandi et al. [89] immobilized the same CALB enzyme on magnetic Fe3O4 coated with titanium oxide and doped with graphene oxide (MTiGO). A 92 % biodiesel yield was recorded at 45 °C reaction temperature, 40 h reaction time, 5:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio, and 4 wt. % catalyst loading. Zhong et al. [90] studied biodiesel production from soybean oil using lipase synthesized from Aspergillus oryzae (AOL). The lipase was immobilized using polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) coated zeolite imidazolate framework nanoleaves (ZIF-L). A biodiesel yield of 94 % was recorded at 40 °C, a methanol-to-oil molar ratio of 4:1, and a reaction time of 24 h. A comparison of the free and immobilized lipase revealed that AOL/PDMS-ZIF-L retained its original activity by up to 90 % after 5 consecutive cycles. In another study, Kamel Ariffin and Idris, [91] synthesized a maghemite composite and crosslinked it with glutaraldehyde to immobilize lipase from Candida antarctica (Fig. 6 ). Upon using the immobilized enzyme to transesterify palm oil, a biodiesel yield of 70.2 % was obtained. The catalyst demonstrated thermal stability over a wide temperature range (27 °C–85 °C), pH stability over the range of 5.5–9.5, and reusability for 7 cycles while maintaining significant activity. Enzymes can also be immobilized using simple bionic methods. For example, Zhang et al. [92] synthesized a recombinant Geobacillus thermocatenulatus lipase 2 (GTL2) which was bionically immobilized in silica. The catalyst was successfully applied for biodiesel production achieving a yield of 91.04 % at 45 °C, catalyst loading of 20 %, 12 h reaction time, and methanol-to-oil molar ratio of 5:1. The catalyst exhibited enhanced thermal stability, storage stability, short-chain alcohol resistance, and achieved a 55.02 % catalytic activity after seven reuse cycles. The study concluded that bionic-immobilization is an effective, economic, and ecological approach for recombinant enzyme immobilization and industrial biocatalysis. Enzyme-catalyzed transesterification can sometimes require a significant quantity of methanol, which could partially inactivate enzymes and reduce their stability [93]. To address this issue, Najjar et al. [94] isolated two bacteria with high thermal and methanol resistance from cooking oil to produce lipase for biodiesel generation. The isolates were identified as Kocuria flava ASU5 and Bacillus circulans ASU11, with the former exhibiting greater alkaline stability, thermal stability, and methanol tolerance. Using the Kocuria flava ASU5 biocatalyst, the optimized biodiesel production achieved a yield of 83.08 % at 60 °C, pH 8, 5 h contact time, and 2:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio. Enzymatic catalysts have proven to be effective for biodiesel production. Their capability to operate at milder temperatures, resulting in low energy consumption, the absence of unwanted saponification reactions, and the production of high-quality products, offers a green approach that promotes a sustainable environment. Despite the advantages of enzymatic catalysts, studies have shown that one major disadvantage of enzyme-catalyzed transesterification is the extended reaction time compared to other catalysts. The immobilization technology and other novel approaches would be required to deal with its limitations such as high production cost, long reaction time, and high concentration. The immobilization technique increases thermal stability while using magnetic materials for the process enhances the recovery of free enzymes. Table 5 shows some studies that have deployed enzymatic catalysts for the production of biodiesel. 3 Synthesis methods for heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production 3.1 Physical/solid mixing Solid mixing is considered to be one of the simplest methods for preparing solid catalysts. It entails the physical combination of two or more powdered precursors, and the process can occur before, during, or after the pulverization of the raw materials, using a mortar or grinder [38]. This method allows the resulting blended material to exhibit the compositional, structural, and physicochemical properties of its constituents, which can be beneficial for the final output [95]. Usually, carriers or supports, such as alumina, silica, or zeolites, are combined with metal oxides or supported metal precursors to produce heterogeneous catalysts through this method [96]. This approach is widely utilized for catalyst preparation due to its simplicity and cost-effectiveness. Nevertheless, factors such as surface area, particle size distribution, and strength of metal-support interactions can influence the performance of the resulting catalyst. Previous researchers have reported the preparation of solid catalysts through solid mixing. In earlier studies, Boro et al. [97] used the physical mixing method to prepare heterogeneous bifunctional catalysts from BaO and Turbonilla striatula-derived CaO for biodiesel production from waste cooking oils while Ofori-Boateng and Lee [98] used cocoa pod husk and MgO-derived solid catalyst to facilitate biodiesel production from soybean oil. Both studies reported high biodiesel yields of 98.7 % and 98.0 % respectively. A recent study by Jazie and Albaaji, [99] prepared heterogeneous catalysts via the physical mixing of calcined bone waste and eggshell for the conversion of waste cooking oil to biodiesel. Their findings indicated that the catalyst made up of a 50:50 mix of calcined bone waste and eggshell (900 °C for 2 h) was able to achieve a biodiesel yield of 94 % at optimized conditions of temperature, time, methanol-to-oil molar ratio and catalyst concentration (60 °C, 4 h, 15:1 and 12 wt. %). In another study, Dai et al. [100] investigated acid-base bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts for soybean oil transesterification into biodiesel. In the study, the catalyst was composed of niobium combined with Li, Na, and K oxides and prepared via solid-state reaction with calcination occurring at 800 °C. Characterization was performed using different techniques. The optimal yield of 98.08 % was achieved with LiNbO3 under 65 °C, 6 h, 24:1 methanol/oil molar ratio, and 2 wt. % catalyst. More recently, Lani et al. [101] investigated a magnetically supported catalyst for the transesterification of used cooking oil. The catalyst, comprised of ZSM-5 zeolite and calcium oxide derived from waste chicken eggshells and rice husks, was combined with magnetite (Fe3O4) via the physical mixing method. The 50CaZ/0.5Fe catalyst demonstrated optimal performance, achieving a biodiesel yield of 91 %, a recovery rate of 88 %, and maintaining a yield of 85 % after four cycles. In these studies, it was generally observed that the blended catalyst samples exhibited better performances compared to the individual samples in converting oil feedstocks to biodiesel, supporting the usefulness of physical mixing as a catalyst preparation method. Some limitations of this method include poor metal dispersion, limited interaction of active phases, and stability, which has been attributed to the weak interaction between the solid precursors [102]. Mota et al. [103] also reported that the physical mixing method does not allow for precise control of crystallite size and distribution and this is thought to result in a catalyst with an open structure. 3.2 Direct calcination In the process of calcination, powdered solid precursors are subjected to high-temperature heating within a furnace, with the ultimate aim of producing heterogeneous catalysts with enhanced physicochemical properties and catalytic activity [104]. This method enhances the specific surface area, pore volume and size, and active site concentration of the resulting catalyst, thus resulting in improved catalytic performance. Factors such as calcination temperature and time play important roles in determining the activity of heterogeneous catalysts prepared via calcination [105]. Farooq and Ramli, [106] and Sirisomboonchai et al. [107] both conducted studies using different types of wastes, namely waste chicken bones and scallop shells, respectively. Their findings showed that calcining these wastes at the appropriate temperature and time enhanced the active surface area, reusability, and conversion efficiency of the resulting catalysts for biodiesel synthesis. It has also been reported that the use of calcined CaO produced from waste oyster shells, as a catalyst for converting WCO to biodiesel, resulted in a decrease in reaction time from 3 h to 2 h, a reduction in reaction temperature from 75 °C to 65 °C, and an increase in biodiesel yield from 80 % to 94.5 % [108]. In a comparable study, a mixed catalyst primarily composed of CaO derived from waste chicken eggshell was subjected to calcination at 650 °C for 8 h and applied for the transesterification of Jatropha oil to produce biodiesel. The calcined catalyst demonstrated better product yield, purity, and reusability when contrasted with the uncalcined catalyst [109]. In a separate investigation, Bedir and Doğan, [81] examined the effect of calcination on waste eggshells, sugar industry waste, marble dust, waste ceramic tiles, and seashells. The results indicated that CaO was the primary mineralogical component in the prepared catalyst samples from calcination. 3.3 Calcination-hydration-dehydration This synthesis method extends the calcination approach by enhancing the basic active site and surface area of the catalysts through sequential hydration and drying of the calcined powdered precursor. To achieve this, the calcined powder or ash is dispersed in deionized or distilled water and refluxed at an appropriate speed, temperature, and time. Subsequently, the mixture is filtered and dried in the oven at an appropriate temperature and time. The solid product obtained from the oven is further dehydrated by calcination to produce pure oxides with superior catalytic characteristics [104]. Researchers have employed the response surface technique to optimize biodiesel production using jatropha oil and a nanocatalyst synthesized from waste snail shells via the calcination-hydration-dehydration process [110]. BET study revealed a surface area of 5.1 m2/g with a pore diameter of 1.1 nm. The study achieved a maximum biodiesel yield of 96.73 % under optimal conditions of 6:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio, 1.4 wt. % catalyst, 60 min reaction time, 55 °C, and 250 rpm. During transesterification, the catalyst exhibited increased catalytic activity and recyclability (Fig. 7 ) [110]. Also, Erchamo et al. [111] investigated the use of an improved eggshell-derived calcium oxide nano-catalyst in a mixed methanol-ethanol system to produce biodiesel from WCO. The eggshell powder was calcined at 900 °C to produce a CaO nano-catalyst, which was then treated with hydration and dehydration to increase its catalytic activity. The porous microstructure of the catalyst transformed from rod-like to honeycomb-like with a higher surface area after hydration and dehydration. In a more recent research, Ao et al. [112] utilized a sequential calcination-hydration-dehydration technique to produce a banana trunk-derived porous sulfonated activated biochar catalyst for biodiesel production from Chlorella vulgaris. They employed different techniques to characterize the catalyst. The study showed that a 5 % concentration of BT-SO3H catalyst could convert 58.29 % of microalgal lipids into biodiesel, showcasing the potential of this catalyst for eco-friendly biodiesel production from microalgae. Furthermore, Ashine et al. [113] optimized biodiesel yield from Argemone mexicana oil using a CaO catalyst generated from chicken eggshells via calcination-hydration-dehydration. At optimized conditions, including a 9.7:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio, 3.05 wt. % catalyst loading, and a 3.01-h reaction time, the catalyst achieved 99.07 % biodiesel yield after being calcined at 700 °C for 2 h. The researchers reported that the catalyst demonstrated significant stability and reusability over more than four cycles. For the environmentally friendly synthesis of biodiesel from high-acid-value oil, Weng et al. [114] developed a process that combines esterification and transesterification reactions, catalyzed by nano-hydrated CaO. The calcium source used to investigate the effects of hydration temperature and time was waste eggshell. The synthetic approach included under-calcination at 875 °C for three hours, hydration at 60 °C for 6 h, and dehydration at 72.5 °C. The alcohol-to-oil mass ratio, reaction temperature, catalyst loading, and reaction time were optimized to 35 %, 60 °C, 2.5 wt. %, and 2 h, respectively. The yield of fatty acid methyl ester was 94.44 % under the optimized conditions, which reduced to 80.52 % after use for eight cycles. Das et al. [115] similarly reported on a simple calcium oxide nanocatalyst that was made by successively calcining, hydrating, and dehydrating waste snail shells to transesterify soybean oil into biodiesel. Under the optimized reaction conditions of a catalyst loading of 6 wt. %, a methanol-to-oil molar ratio of 8:1, a reaction duration of 3 h, and a temperature of 70 °C, a high biodiesel yield of 96.1 % was achieved. The catalyst demonstrated remarkable stability, allowing for six cycles of continuous usage without a significant decrease in catalytic activity. 3.4 Wet impregnation The wet impregnation method of catalyst synthesis is one of the simplest techniques for preparing catalysts. Its low costs, conservative utilization of materials, speed, and technical simplicity have contributed to its widespread acceptance in catalyst synthesis [57]. Catalysts synthesis through the wet impregnation method entails the dispersion of the active phase (supported phase) onto a solid material (support) through the creation of a homogeneous suspension of the precursor solution. The support is immersed in this solution, facilitating the adsorption of the precursor onto its surface [96]. This process is typically conducted at ambient temperature, ensuring uniform distribution of the active phase. Solvent evaporation is promoted through continuous agitation or the introduction of an inert gas flow, enhancing precursor deposition. Subsequently, the impregnated support undergoes drying and calcination to stabilize the active phase, thereby improving catalytic efficiency and structural integrity for optimal performance in biodiesel production [17]. Although this method faces a drawback in the synthesis of catalysts with a high concentration of active agents, nonetheless it has been effectively used to synthesize supported and mixed catalysts that promote transesterification/esterification reactions [116]. Several studies have reported positive results from the use of wet impregnation for the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts for transesterification reactions. For instance, Gonçalves et al. [117] produced biodiesel from waste cooking oil using a magnetic acid heterogeneous catalyst MoO3/SrFe2O4 synthesized via wet-impregnation and co-precipitation technique. The co-precipitation technique was used to synthesize SrFe2O4 while the magnetic MoO3/SrFe2O4 catalyst was synthesized by wet impregnation of MoO3 on SrFe2O4. They investigated the effect of MoO3 dosage on biodiesel yield and reported a maximum biodiesel yield of 95.4 % at optimal conditions of 164 °C reaction temperature, 40:1 alcohol-to-oil molar ratio, 10 wt. % catalyst dosage in 4 h reaction time. Similarly, Gonçalves et al. [118] utilized the wet impregnation method to synthesize a magnetic solid acid catalyst, MoO3/RHA-CoFe2O4, from rice husk ash (RHA) and cobalt ferrite. They combined 1 g of RHA with 30 wt. % CoFe2O4 and dissolved in 40 mL of water and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O to attain a molybdenum content of 10–40 wt. %. The mixture was then stirred at ambient temperature for 3 h, followed by drying at 80 °C for 12 h and calcining at 450 °C for 2 h (Fig. 8 ). The resulting catalyst produced 94.6 % ester content in biodiesel at 160 °C, 20:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio, 6 wt. % catalyst, and 3 h reaction time. After 10 cycles, the catalyst retained more than 70 % ester content, demonstrating its excellent stability and bifunctional catalytic characteristics. Sulaiman et al. [119] utilized wet impregnation to synthesize CaO/RHA and SrO/RHA catalysts for biodiesel production from waste cooking oil. CaO and SrO were dissolved in water with RHA at 10:90, 20:80, and 30:70 wt. % ratios, mixed, filtered, aged at 80 °C for 24 h, and calcined at 700–900 °C for 5 h. The 10SrO/90RHA catalyst (900 °C) produced 89.97 % biodiesel, while the 10CaO/90RHA catalyst (800 °C) produced 83.09 %. The optimal conditions for 10SrO/90RHA were 65 °C, 6 wt. % catalyst, 1:18 oil-to-methanol molar ratio, and 1 h reaction time. Falowo et al. [120] investigated biodiesel production from WCO using a bifunctional catalyst made from calcined eggshells and ferric sulfate. The CaO precursor, calcined at 800 °C for 3 h, was impregnated with ferric sulfate in a 1:1 ratio. The catalyst was mixed, dried at 100 °C, and then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. Ca (20.7 %), Fe (18.5 %), S (4.5 %), and O (54.8 %) were revealed from the characterization tests carried out. The catalyst produced a maximum biodiesel yield of 89.94 wt. % and was reusable for four cycles. Using palm oil as feedstock, De and Boxi, [121] produced biodiesel with heterogeneous TiO2 and Cu-TiO2 nanocatalyst. They investigated the percentage concentration of TiO2 and the effect of Cu impregnation with TiO2, synthesized by wet impregnation, on biodiesel yield. It was concluded that 3 wt. % TiO2 concentration gave a maximum biodiesel yield of 84.5 % and a significant yield of 89.09 % was observed when 2 % Cu concentration was impregnated on TiO2. In a recent study conducted by Hameed et al. [122], biodiesel was prepared by the transesterification of WCO using an activated carbon-supported calcium oxide catalyst. The AC-supported CaO was synthesized through pyrolysis of peach shell followed by chemical activation with KOH and then calcium loading through the wet impregnation method. They investigated the optimal catalyst preparation conditions on biodiesel yield and concluded that the calcination temperature of 650 °C and CaO loading of 20 wt. % gave the highest catalytic performance. This improvement in catalytic activity was mainly attributed to the enhanced basicity of the catalysts, after wet impregnation on the AC support. 3.5 Co-precipitation This is a process of synthesizing catalysts via the combination of alkali solutions and aqueous phase metal salts, resulting in the formation of metal hydroxides and/or carbonates [123]. Precipitating agents such as ammonium hydroxide, KOH, NaOH, or potassium carbonate are subsequently added to the mixture, followed by stirring. The pH of the resulting precipitate is then maintained at alkaline conditions, and the product is oven-dried to eliminate moisture. Subsequently, the catalyst undergoes activation treatments through calcination to convert the active components into oxides [124]. Although this technique requires a significant amount of chemicals, it has been proven effective across various catalyst concentrations and is effective in preventing particle agglomeration [125]. Yusuff et al. [30] utilized this method to produce a mixed oxides catalyst for converting waste frying oil into biodiesel. In their study, fine powder obtained from waste chicken eggshells was combined with nickel nitrate, cobalt nitrate, and anthill powder, which were dissolved in deionized water at 80 °C. The mixture was then agitated for 5 h. Na2CO3 was added to the resulting slurry and continuously agitated for 2 h at 80 °C. The slurry was allowed to coagulate and then filtered. The residue was dehydrated and heated to 110 °C for 12 h before being calcined at 1000 °C for 4 h. The produced catalyst exhibited high stability, yielded 90.23 % biodiesel, and could be reused four times. Tayeb et al. [126] conducted a study on the use of a nano-CaO catalyst in the production of biodiesel. The nano CaO was prepared through co-precipitation and characterized for its high purity, small crystal size, thermal stability, and large surface area. Waste cooking oil was converted into biodiesel through transesterification using the prepared nano CaO. The optimal parameters for the reaction were predicted using a response surface approach. The biodiesel produced was analyzed using FTIR spectroscopy and GC–MS, and it was determined to satisfy the ASTM D6571 standards. The study therefore demonstrated the excellent catalytic activity and efficiency of nano CaO in biodiesel production. Bekele et al. [84] developed alkali and bifunctional catalysts for the production of waste frying oil methyl ester (WFOME) using KNO3 impregnation to make catalysts from coffee husk (CH) and CH combined with Eragrostis tef straw (TS). Zirconia was integrated into the bifunctional catalysts through precipitation and impregnation processes. The characterization tests revealed that the C-Mix (CH-TS) and C-45 (CH) catalysts were highly active and produced WFOME yields of 98.08 % and 97 %, respectively, at 65 °C, 1 h, 15:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio, and 5–7 wt. % catalyst. C-Mix had the highest moisture resistance, while C-45 had the best reusability. Ghosh et al. [127] investigated biodiesel production from castor oil using a magnetic nanocatalyst prepared from waste Citrus limetta peel ash (CLPA@Fe3O4). CLPA was synthesized by carbonizing peels at 300 °C for 1 h, followed by extraction in water at 90 °C (Fig. 9 ). The magnetic Fe3O4 support was produced using co-precipitation, coupled with CLPA extract. The optimal biodiesel yield was 97.92 %, attained with 30 wt. % methanol, 6 wt. % catalyst, 60 °C, and 3 h. 3.6 Sol-gel Sol-gel is a wet chemical technique for synthesizing oxide-based nano-catalysts initiated by hydrolysis and condensation of hydrolyzable precursors [128]. These weak ligands precursors (metal alkoxide, nitrates, sulfates, or carboxylates) are converted to sol through heating and stirring via hydrolysis/alcoholysis. The resultant sol is then dried using appropriate methods to form a gel, which is subsequently crushed, sized, and calcined to meet the desired requirement for application. Its simplicity, high purity of products, and high production efficiency are some of the highlighted merits that have attracted its application in catalyst preparation [129]. In an earlier study, Moradi et al. [41] utilized the sol-gel method to synthesize a CaO/SiO2 catalyst for the transesterification of corn oil into FAME. CaO was derived from waste chicken eggshell and combined with de-ionized water and tetraethyl orthosilicate. The mixture was then refluxed for 2 h at 65 °C with a stirring speed of 400 rpm. After adding a sufficient amount of NH4OH and heating at 75 °C for 5 h, the excess moisture in the mixture gradually evaporated, resulting in a viscose gel. The gel was then dehydrated at 110 °C for 20 h, crushed, and sieved through a suitable screen before being calcined at 850 °C for 3 h in a furnace. The catalyst demonstrated effectiveness in producing a biodiesel yield of 85.6 %. Other research has also been conducted to examine the efficiency of catalysts synthesized via the sol-gel technique. Salim et al. [130] investigated the transesterification reaction of sunflower oil (SFO) using a ZnO catalyst synthesized using the sol-gel technique. Their findings showed a good performance of ZnO in transesterifying SFO to FAME with a 71 % yield under conditions of methanol-to-oil molar ratio of 20:1, catalyst loading of 4.7 wt. %, and a reaction temperature of 70 °C for 3 h. In a recent study, Iskandar et al. [131] utilized CaO·SiO2 catalysts made via the sol-gel method with various tapioca flour binders (1–5 %) and calcination temperatures (600–1000 °C) for biodiesel production. While optimal biodiesel production was achieved, the excessively high temperatures (900 - 1000 °C) resulted in agglomeration, which reduced the catalyst's effectiveness. Also, Abu-Ghazala et al. [132] used the sol-gel method to produce a CaO/Al2O3 nano-catalyst from aluminum industrial waste (AIW) for biodiesel synthesis. AIW was first crushed into fine powder to enhance its specific surface area, then dissolved in 3 M potassium hydroxide solution. The resulting mixture was filtered using a filtration pump to obtain a clear solution, and the pH was adjusted to 9. The mixture was continuously stirred at 40 °C for 24 h, forming a gel-like aluminum hydroxide (Al(OH)₃) solution. The precipitated Al(OH)₃ was separated via filtration, thoroughly washed with deionized water, dried overnight at 80 °C, and subsequently calcined in a muffle furnace at 1000 °C for 6 h, yielding white powdered alumina (Fig. 10 ). The results revealed that the best biodiesel production of 95 % was obtained with a 3 wt. % catalyst at 45 °C, 3 h, and a methanol-to-oil ratio of 7:1. The catalyst also demonstrated remarkable stability across five reaction cycles. Table 6 summarizes some of the works reviewed in this section and shows that the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel has been extensively investigated using various techniques, including solid mixing, calcination, calcination-hydration-dehydration, wet impregnation, co-precipitation, and sol-gel methods. Among these, solid mixing is a cost-effective and simple method, but it often suffers from weak metal-support interactions, which may compromise catalyst performance. Calcination techniques, on the other hand, enhance physicochemical properties and active site dispersion, leading to improved catalytic activity and reusability. The sequential hydration-dehydration method further refines these properties, resulting in better catalytic performance and stability. Wet impregnation and co-precipitation methods allow for the synthesis of highly active and stable catalysts, but precise control over process parameters is necessary to avoid particle agglomeration. The sol-gel technique, known for producing high-purity catalysts, effectively integrates various precursors to form robust catalytic systems. Notably, the incorporation of waste materials as catalyst precursors aligns with the sustainability goals of biodiesel production. Overall, these synthesis strategies highlight the critical balance between methodological simplicity, process control, and the desired catalytic properties necessary for efficient biodiesel production. The various catalyst systems reported demonstrate the potential for optimizing reaction conditions to achieve high biodiesel yields, emphasizing the effectiveness of these synthesis methods in advancing biodiesel technology. 4 Role of synthesis methods in catalyst properties and performance for biodiesel production The synthesis method plays a crucial role in determining the properties and subsequent performance of catalysts for biodiesel production. The choice of synthesis method can significantly affect the structural and morphological properties of the catalysts, which in turn affects their catalytic activity, performance, and stability in biodiesel production [5]. Several methods, such as the sol-gel method, wet impregnation, co-precipitation, and calcination methods, as discussed in the previous sections, have been used to prepare heterogeneous catalysts, including nanocatalysts, from waste-based materials. Hence, this section provides a comprehensive elucidation of the impact of these synthesis methods on catalyst properties, such as crystallite and particle size, surface area, pore structure, morphology, and metal dispersion, and their subsequent performance in biodiesel production. 4.1 Effect on crystallite and particle size The quality and reproducibility of biodiesel catalysts are essential for large-scale commercial applications. Furthermore, characterizing the various physical and chemical properties of these heterogeneous catalysts is critical to their acceptance and use [136]. The size of the crystallites of a catalyst is an important characteristic that influences a reaction by modifying the number of active sites accessible for the reaction. It is the smallest unit of an individual particle in a catalyst material and is usually determined using the Scherrer equation [137]. A smaller crystallite size increases the surface-area-to-volume ratio, resulting in more active sites for the reaction and potentially accelerating the reaction rate [138]. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis has been recognized as a powerful tool for studying the crystallite and particle sizes of catalysts [139]. XRD also provides valuable information concerning the bulk structure and composition of solid catalyst materials, thus promoting the understanding of their structural properties, as well as atomic and molecular arrangements in crystalline catalysts. Due to its wide acceptance as a viable technique to determine the crystallite and particle sizes of biodiesel catalysts, several researchers have utilized the XRD method. For example, a ZnO catalyst was produced using a modified hydrothermal technique and subsequently analyzed via the XRD technique. It was determined that the ZnO catalyst possessed crystalline hexagonal wurtzite nanoparticles, with an average crystallite size of 30–36 nm at various reaction times [140]. Rabiei et al. [139] also compared models for studying the crystal size of hydroxyapatite crystals from naturally occurring materials such as chicken, pig, and cow bones using XRD. The results obtained showed accurate values ranging between 4 nm and 65 nm, except for the straight line method in the Scherrer model, which gave an unrealistic size of 1371 nm. They noted that the error estimation of the crystallite size value of 1371 nm came from the attempt to use all the selected peaks simultaneously in the estimation using the straight line method in the Scherrer equation. In this context, the y-intercept had no physical meaning. They recommended that in order to correct the use of the Scherrer equation, the linear plot should be forced to pass through the origin. More recently, a study by Farokhi et al. [141] reported Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 as the optimal catalyst for the conversion of neem seed oil to biodiesel. The catalyst was prepared via sol-gel and thermal decomposition methods to achieve a crystallite size of 34.29 nm and eventually obtain a 93.91 % optimal biodiesel yield. According to Erchamo et al. [111], the catalytic activity of heterogeneous catalysts can be improved for enhanced biodiesel yield by reducing the crystal size of the catalyst using special methods to synthesize a nanoparticle. The use of nanocatalysts in transesterification reactions can speed up the process and is not affected by the free fatty acids and water content of feedstocks, offering cost advantages due to their reusability. For example, Liu and Zhang [142] compared particulate ZnO (1–2 µm) to ZnO nanocrystals (100–500 nm) prepared via precipitation method and layer-by-layer nucleation and growth. The results showed that the nanocatalysts had a better biodiesel yield (76.5 %), which was higher than the biodiesel yield of 46.2 % obtained when the particulate ZnO was used. In addition, a MgO nanocatalyst was prepared via co-precipitation using a NaOH solution and characterized for biodiesel production from non-edible yellow oleander oil [143]. The preparation method produced an average crystal size of 20 nm, which produced an optimal biodiesel yield of 93.1 %. Other reports have specifically compared the effects of two different synthesis methods on the crystallite and particle sizes of synthetic catalysts. For instance, three different synthesis methods, hydrothermal, impregnation, and co-precipitation, have been used to prepare Ca-Zn-Ce/Al2O3 catalysts from synthetic chemicals for the transesterification of palm oil to biodiesel [144]. The results revealed that the catalyst prepared via the hydrothermal method had the smallest crystallite size of 29.1 nm and was the most efficient (97.85 %) in producing biodiesel, indicating its superior catalytic activity. Another study on palm oil utilized the wet impregnation method to prepare a Cu-TiO2 synthetic catalyst for its transesterification reaction and compared this with the direct calcination of the TiO2 catalyst. The results obtained showed that the synthesized nano-TiO2 catalyst impregnated with Cu (nano-Cu-TiO2) had particle sizes in the range of 80–150 nm, and this was preferred to that prepared with the calcination method as it gave a higher biodiesel yield of 90.93 % compared to the 84.5 % obtained with the direct calcination method [121]. Biogenic waste materials have also been utilized as precursors for the green synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts. Fatimah et al. [145] utilized bamboo leaves as precursors to provide support for a ZrO2-based catalyst in microwave-assisted biodiesel production from soybean oil. The bamboo leaf was prepared by the calcination method and wet impregnation with ZrO2, and the two methods were compared. The crystallite size of dispersed ZrO2 obtained through the wet impregnation method, calculated using Scherrer's equation was obtained as 48. 37 nm and this was determined to possess better inherent catalytic properties resulting in a higher biodiesel yield of 95.99 %. A similar method was used to impregnate potassium hydroxide on a black pepper seed precursor for the conversion of palm oil to biodiesel [146]. The particle size analysis revealed 54.55 µm and 21.68 µm for the uncalcined and calcined catalyst (post-impregnation). Calcination reduced the particle size by more than 50 %, leading to better mass transfer and improved biodiesel conversion. Moringa leaves were also utilized as a sustainable precursor for heterogeneous catalyst synthesis via calcination at 500 °C, for biodiesel production from soybean oil. The calcination conditions produced crystals of calcite, fairchildite, and dolomite observed at 36.5 nm, which resulted in low biodiesel yields (< 60 %) at 3 wt. % catalyst loading, especially due to the presence of calcite (CaCO3). Hence, higher quantities of catalysts were required to achieve increased yields of up to 86 % owing to the low basicity of the calcined catalyst [147]. In a later work by Aleman-Ramirez et al. [148], Pouteria sapota was used to produce a Ca and K-based catalyst with crystallite sizes of 29.1 nm and 35.5 nm for fairchildite and dicalcium phosphate crystals, respectively. The presence of these crystals was observed after calcination and activation of the catalyst, which, in turn, yielded 92 % biodiesel each from sunflower oil and soybean oil. However, in the case of waste or biomass-derived catalysts themselves, several studies over the years have concluded that CaO, amongst other biomass or waste material-derived metal oxides (such as ZnO and MgO) and hydroxides, exhibits the highest catalytic activity for the synthesis of biodiesel [56]. An important property of CaO catalysts is their active sites, which improve as the size of the catalyst decreases; hence, a smaller catalyst particle/crystallite size will result in a reduced catalyst quantity needed for the reaction, thereby enhancing its efficiency [149]. In an early study, Degfie et al. [150] synthesized nanosized CaO using thermal decomposition and calcination at 500 °C. High-purity nanocrystals were revealed by XRD, with an average particle size of 29 nm and at an optimal catalyst loading of 1 wt. %, giving an optimal biodiesel yield of 96 %. Anbia et al. [151] used co-precipitation and impregnation method to prepare CaMgAl(O) and Ca-MgAl nanocatalysts respectively for biodiesel production.
