The impregnation method (Ca-MgAl) with a lower crystallite size of 20.04 nm, showed better mechanical stability with a lower Ca leaching (8 %) than the co-precipitation method (45.8 %), although both had a comparable biodiesel yield (∼90 %). In a study, cockle shell-derived catalysts, namely, CaO and nano-CaO were synthesized by calcination and optimized thermal hydration–dehydration methods, respectively [152]. The use of thermal hydration–dehydration synthesis produced highly crystalline catalysts for both the CaO particles and nanocrystal particles. Nano-CaO prepared via the optimized thermal hydration–dehydration method was found to have better structural properties. It was reported that the hydration and dehydration steps caused the fractionation of material resulting in smaller crystallite sizes which improved the surface area and pore volume and consequently resulted in a higher biodiesel yield of 94.13 %. Erchamo et al. [111] also reported improved biodiesel production from waste cooking oil using an enhanced eggshell‐derived CaO nanocatalyst produced via the hydration-dehydration method. The XRD results revealed that the use of the hydration-dehydration method (800 °C for 3 h) transformed the catalyst into a porous microstructure by decreasing the average crystallite size to 13.53 nm, from 21.3 nm obtained from the direct calcination method (900 °C for 3 h) with a corresponding biodiesel yield of 94 %. Table 7 provides a summary of some of the works reviewed in this section. From the studies reviewed, it can be seen that several authors have investigated different synthesis methods for deriving heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production. The existing literature underscores the significance of synthesis methods in determining the size of catalyst crystallites and their impact on the performance of biodiesel production based on their XRD results. Smaller crystallite sizes, achieved through processes such as hydrothermal synthesis, wet impregnation, co-precipitation, sol-gel, and thermal decomposition, enhance the surface-area-to-volume ratio, thereby increasing the availability of active sites and improving the catalytic performance. The use of techniques such as XRD aids in the characterization of these catalysts by providing information about their structural features. Optimal biodiesel yields are obtained with catalysts synthesized to achieve crystallite sizes on the nanoscale, emphasizing the need for careful control over synthesis conditions. In summary, the careful selection and optimization of synthesis methods that result in catalysts with smaller crystallite sizes are important for improving the efficiency of biodiesel production. 4.2 Effect on pore properties The suitability of the catalysts for biodiesel synthesis is also dependent on several factors, including the surface area and the pore structure of the catalyst. Hence, heterogeneous catalysts are preferred over homogeneous catalysts due to their reusability and the ability to be manipulated to achieve specific characteristics, such as a higher surface area or a more improved pore structure as these properties greatly impact the efficiency of biodiesel production [5]. For instance, higher surface area and pore volume will enhance reactant and product diffusion to and from active sites, prevent pore blockage, and maintain structural integrity during reactions, which is crucial for improving the catalyst's reusability [153,154]. These properties can be tuned depending on the synthesis method adopted. It is important to acknowledge that some studies have contradicted this assertion, suggesting that a greater specific surface area does not necessarily result in increased catalytic activity [144]. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis is typically used in conjunction with the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method to determine the specific surface area, pore volume, and diameter distributions of catalysts. Generally, pore diameters between 2 and 50 nm are classified as mesopores, while between 0.5–2 nm and 50–1000 nm are referred to as micropores and macropores, respectively. Mesoporous characteristics facilitate efficient mass transfer in transesterification by offering a sufficient external surface area for active sites. In this section, several synthesis methods will be reviewed to understand the effect the synthesis method and individual synthesis steps have on the catalyst surface area, pore structure, and biodiesel yield. Several catalyst synthesis methods and steps have been explored for their effects on catalyst surface texture properties. For instance, Qu et al. [144], compared three different methods (hydrothermal, impregnation, and co-precipitation) for preparing solid catalysts for biodiesel production. It was established that the catalyst prepared using the hydrothermal method had higher surface area, pore volume, and diameter (12.204 m2/g, 0.107 cm3/g, and 32.84 nm) compared to the co-precipitation (2.941 m2/g, 0.013 cm3/g, and 16.82 nm) and wet impregnation method (0.743 m2/g, 0.004 cm3/g, and 18.32 nm) which was reflected in its higher biodiesel yield of 97.85 %. The limited performance of the other methods was attributed to the higher crystallite size of the catalyst which reduced their surface area and porosity, causing a decline in the contact area and mass transfer between the catalyst and reactant molecules and negatively impacting catalytic activity [154]. In another study, Feng et al. [155] used ZnCl2 to activate a catalyst prepared from the exoskeleton of the black soldier flies (Hermetia illucens L.) and then impregnated with phosphotungstic acid. Their study compared the effects of the calcination, activation, and acid impregnation steps on the catalyst surface area and pore structure. The initial calcination step yielded catalysts with the largest surface area of 14.67 m2/g, and the surface area decreased with subsequent treatment, i.e. activation gave 12.10 m2/g, while the final acid treatment reduced it to 6.35 m2/g. However, the slight decrease in surface area between the calcination and activation steps did not translate to a lower biodiesel yield since the pore volume and diameter of the catalyst increased, enhancing its performance [156]. Indeed, the application of optimal calcination, activation, and phosphotungstic acid impregnation for the catalyst promoted the transesterification reaction, enabling a biodiesel yield of 93.87 % at optimal conditions. Numerous studies have indicated that an increase in the active component content in the catalyst during wet and incipient impregnation leads to a reduction in the surface area of the catalyst, along with an increase in biodiesel yield up to an optimal level. Beyond this point, however, the biodiesel yield begins to decline. This phenomenon is evident in two studies by Ayoob and Fadhil [157,158], who impregnated KOH and LiOH2 on pyrolyzed waste tire-activated carbon. As KOH and LiOH2 loading increased, the surface area of the impregnated activated carbon-based catalyst reduced; however, the biodiesel yield increased up to an optimum value (possibly where the accessible pores were filled), after which a decline in the yield was observed. Another study by Ma et al. [159] showed similar results when a lignin-based catalyst was impregnated with ZnCl2 to promote the production of biodiesel. The study, which explored the effect of the impregnation at various ZnCl2 loadings on the surface area and pore structure, showed that the specific surface area and pore volume increased with an increase in the concentration of the activation compound until an optimal surface area and pore volume point (lignin-to-ZnCl2 ratio = 1:2) of 1709.0 m2/g and 1.08 cm3/g, respectively, after which a decline was observed. This understanding is further supported in a recent study by Okoduwa et al. [17], which found that the impregnation of the catalyst precursor resulted in a lower surface area (121.548 m2/g) than the pristine catalyst (301.510 m2/g). However, other studies that reported findings on catalyst pore structure and surface area have not definitively linked the loading of the active component to pore diameter, pore volume, surface area, and biodiesel yield during catalyst synthesis by wet impregnation. This lack of correlation may be attributed to multiple factors, such as the concentration of the active component (e.g., aqueous acid, alkaline, or salt solution) [160], the inherent characteristics of the support material, the accessibility of reactants in pore spaces [62], and the ionic radius of the active component, particularly in the case of metallic ions [161]. For example, in the same study by Ma et al. [159], the authors also examined the effect of ZnCl2 impregnation on the pore diameter and volume. Unlike the surface area, the pore diameter increased with increasing concentration of the activation agent to 2.9 nm, even though this was not selected as the optimally activated material. The surface area of the optimal catalyst (lignin-to-ZnCl2 ratio = 1:2), after carbonization at different temperatures was found to increase to a maximum of 1769.4 m2/g as the carbonization temperature increased from 300 to 500 °C. However, the catalyst obtained after carbonization at 450 °C was selected as the best, having the highest pore volume (1.08 cm3/g) at the optimal surface area (1709.0 m2/g) but a moderate pore diameter of 2.8 nm. The activation step significantly improved the surface area and pore volume of the microporous activated catalyst (MLC-S), i.e. 1042.6 m2/g and 0.59 cm3/g when compared to the unactivated but carbonized and sulfonated lignin catalyst (LC-S), i.e. 5.9 m2/g and 0.01 cm3/g. Although the optimally selected catalyst at the end of the preparation did not have the best pore diameter, volume, or even surface area, it, however, had a relatively higher biodiesel yield (> 90 %) among the compared catalysts. Another study by Tang et al. [62] compared the effect of sulfonation on three different waste-derived activated carbon. The addition of the sulfonic acid group (−SO3H) reduced the surface areas and pore volumes of the three activated carbon. The pore diameter, however, decreased in one of the materials but increased in the other two materials. The large pore volumes might be obtained from the smaller pore sizes, which might have prohibited the accessibility of reactants with larger molecular sizes. Hence, the average pore size of the catalyst (> 2.0 nm) was an important factor for good catalytic performance. Since the activated carbons from the three materials and their corresponding sulfonated catalyst exhibited average pore diameters of over 2.0 nm, the largest pore size was no longer a criterion because the FFA and triglyceride molecules could pass through the pores without distortion, making the sites accessible enough for the reactants molecule [162]. Similarly, in a previously discussed work by Okoduwa et al. [17], the wet impregnation of nickel and strontium metallic ions within the biogenic waste matrix of waste marble tiles and cow horn increased the pore diameter but like the surface area, it also decreased the pore volume of the catalyst. This catalyst led to a relatively high optimal biodiesel yield of 98 %. Another study that produced four different catalysts from coffee husk and Eragrostis tef straw using a combination of several synthesis methods, including precipitation, impregnation, and physical mixing, showed a similar phenomenon [163]. The catalyst prepared by physical mixing of the coffee husk and E. tef straw and impregnation had the second lowest surface area (0.873 m2/g), while the catalyst prepared from the impregnation of coffee husk alone had the highest surface area (2.644 m2/g). However, the catalyst with the lower surface area showed a better biodiesel yield (98.08 %) than the one with the highest surface area catalyst (92.69 %), which was the least among the four catalysts. The study attributed this to the excellent interaction between the active site and the catalyst surface forming just the adequate amounts of K2SiO3 and K2Ca(CO3)2 compounds, and invariably, lower aggregates. Zhang et al. [164] produced a sulfonated silica-supported catalyst (SiO2@Cs-SO3H) with a sulfonation (impregnation) procedure using chitosan extract (Cs-SO3H) as the precursor and nano-SiO2 as a support. They noted that for a catalyst support to be a suitable carrier of the active components, it was important to improve the specific surface area of the catalyst, thus leading to better catalytic performance. Their synthesis method produced a catalyst with a surface area of 21.82 m2/g and a pore volume and pore diameter distribution of 0.022 cm2/g and < 20 nm, respectively. This catalyst enabled the production of 98.2 % biodiesel yield. In a more recent study by Tang et al. [165], the effect of the catalysis by carbonization and impregnation by the sulfonation method was evaluated on the catalyst surface area and pore structure using the BET and BHJ techniques. The waste-derived catalyst, which was prepared from black soldier fly larvae shells, was screened using different carbonization and sulfonating agents. The optimized sulfonated catalyst was then compared with the unsulfonated catalyst to elucidate the effect of the precursor treatment method. The catalyst produced by dissolution and carbonization only had a larger surface area of 21.12 m2/g, a pore volume of 0.024 cm3/g and a pore diameter of 10.1 nm, and then, after sulfonation, the catalyst properties were reduced to 5.41 m2/g, 0.022 cm3/g and 19.5 nm respectively, signifying the presence of the −SO3H group in the catalyst internal matrix, with the sulfonated catalyst giving a biodiesel yield of 93.2 % [159,164]. A similar and recent study compared three catalysts prepared by impregnating a rice husk precursor with strontium oxide (SrO), impregnating the same precursor with CaO, and then using the pristine precursor as a catalyst [119]. The pristine precursor-only catalyst had the least surface area (8.3 m2/g) and the lowest biodiesel yield (71.29 %), supporting the impact of impregnation (dopants) on the catalytic activity and surface textural properties. The study showed that the SrO-doped catalyst had the highest surface area at various calcination temperatures compared to the CaO-doped catalyst. Notably, at the optimal conditions, the SrO catalyst had a higher surface area of 13.8 m2/g compared to the surface area of the CaO catalyst of 11.8 m2/g, translating to biodiesel yields of 89.97 % and 83.09 %, respectively. The CaO-impregnated catalyst had the highest pore diameter at optimal (19.39 nm) than the SrO (12.04 nm), possibly due to the smaller ionic radius of calcium compared to strontium, which influences the free movement of calcium ions (Ca2+) and creating larger void compared to strontium oxide (SrO) [166]. Although impregnating the catalyst with metallic ions and highly catalytic active groups reduces the surface area with varying pore conditions, it is, however, noteworthy that this synthesis method increases the basicity of the catalyst (for base catalyst), countering the negative effect of impregnation on surface area and pore structure, and ultimately resulting in a higher biodiesel yield [144]. Furthermore, from the above studies, it is observed that the use of simple preparation methods like calcination alone, can produce a catalyst or catalyst support with a very high surface area suitable for subsequent processes like activation or impregnation [167]. However, this increase in surface area does not always correlate with better catalytic activity. This observation is corroborated in the study by Guo et al. [168], where activated carbon was calcined and impregnated with silver, cesium, and potassium, and then H6PV3MoW8O40 acid by incipient impregnation. The BET and BJH characterizations showed that the first calcination step alone produced the largest surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter (1171 m2/g, 1.05 cm3/g, and 3.7 nm) but had the least biodiesel conversion (5.0 %), while the lowest surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter (309.8 m2/g, 0.23 cm3/g, and 2.98 nm) from the 35 % H6PV3MoW8O40/AC-Ag catalyst gave the highest yield (90.5 %), signifying the presence of active acidic sites and the creation of more mesopores [168]. An optimal surface area and pore structure are desirable for providing accessible active sites for the heterogeneously catalytic transesterification reaction. The effect of the calcination-only method of catalyst preparation is buttressed by a comparative study of a calcined white brick waste-derived catalyst with the ordinarily ground (non-calcined) catalyst [169]. The effect of calcination was observed in the increasing specific surface area from 0.63 m2/g for the raw precursor to 1.41 m2/g for the catalyst calcined at 700 °C. The pore diameter and volume reduced from 2.1 to 1.8 nm and from 0.65 to 0.32 × 10–3 cm3/g. This effect was evident in the biodiesel yield, as 0 % was recorded for the uncalcined catalyst, while ∼92.7 % was achieved for the calcined catalyst. Another study by Bargole et al. [170] explored the effect of multiple calcination steps on the surface area, pore structure, and biodiesel yield of waste cooking oil. Pristine marble waste (MW) powder was compared to precalcined marble waste powder (MWC), acid-pretreated powder without precalcination (MWAC), acid-pretreated and calcined powder (MWCAC), and laboratory-grade CaO. The results showed that the pristine catalyst (MW) had the least surface area (0.4299 m2/g) while the calcined had the highest surface area (5.2540 m2/g), which was also reflected in the higher pore volume compared to the uncalcined (2.38 × 10−2 cm3/g vs. 2.1 × 10−3 cm3/g). The MWC had a better surface area and pore volume than the laboratory CaO, further bolstering the effect of calcination on surface area and pore structures. The comparison of MWAC with MWCAC, revealed that MWCAC had a lower surface area (1.4301 m2/g) and higher biodiesel yield (95.45 %) than MWAC (2.0463 m2/g and 60.83 %), and this was likely due to the larger surface pore volume created by pre-calcination, for the filling by acid sites. A more recent study by Buasri et al. [171] compared a calcined CaO-based catalyst from a golden apple snail shell with a calcined CaO-K2O catalyst from the combination of snail shells and banana peels. The addition of the banana peels increased the surface area and pore volume of the catalyst from 10.88 m2/g to 14.62 m2/g and 0.069 cm3/g to 0.074 cm3/g. The addition of K2O reduced the surface diffusion of Ca and inhibited sintering, maintaining a larger surface area for the CaO-K2O catalyst, which enhanced catalyst activity in the transesterification process, producing a 97.06 % biodiesel yield. From the works reviewed in this section, it was observed that the efficiency of biodiesel production is heavily influenced by the impact of synthesis methods on the pore properties of catalysts, such as surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter. Studies (Table 8 ) have shown that increasing surface area and pore volume through methods like hydrothermal synthesis enhances reactant diffusion and prevents pore blockage, leading to the maintenance of structural integrity and catalytic activity. The reviewed works above however show that a higher surface area does not always lead to improved catalytic performance. In some cases, optimal biodiesel yields have been obtained from catalysts with lower surface areas but stronger interaction between active sites and reactants. Indeed, while the calcination process was found to significantly increase surface area and pore volume, subsequent impregnation with active components may reduce these properties but enhance catalyst basicity, leading to improved biodiesel yields. Therefore, it is important to balance surface area and pore structure optimization with the incorporation of active sites to maximize the efficiency of biodiesel production. 4.3 Effect on morphology Understanding the morphology of a catalyst in heterogeneous catalysis is essential for optimizing the catalytic performance to meet specific process needs. The morphology of a catalyst refers to the physical arrangement of the internal structure of the catalyst, including its size, shape, and distribution of the catalytically active material [18]. Most studies in heterogeneous catalysis focus on enhancing the catalytic active phase for a specific reaction to boost product yield. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) is the most common and interpretable method for assessing catalyst morphology due to its capacity to aid in the identification of catalyst preparation issues such as improper distribution of active components in the catalyst [172]. As one of the simplest and most widely used methods of preparing biodiesel catalysts, especially biomass-based catalysts, calcination changes the morphology of the precursor by breaking down the complex organic matter through the removal of volatile compounds, giving rise to a more porous functionalized catalyst [17]. For instance, the effect of calcination on the morphology of raw powdered moringa used as catalyst precursor was studied by Aleman-Ramirez et al. [147] using SEM images. The raw precursor was characterized by a non-uniform particle size macroporous morphology with agglomeration (Fig. 11a ). At the same time, for the calcined catalyst (at 500 °C), the effect of calcination was evident in the smaller particle size. However, particle agglomeration was still evident, but with slits, cracks, and pores of different shapes (Fig. 11b). In a similar work, Aleman-Ramirez et al. [148], studied the effect of calcination on the Pouteria sapota catalyst using SEM images. The calcined catalyst, compared with the uncalcined catalyst, revealed a more porous and spongy morphology with lesser particle size, indicative of a higher surface area with more active catalytic surface sites. Metals and metallic oxides have been impregnated on biomaterials to create a better particle regularity than their pristine counterparts for better catalytic activity [173]. For instance, a composite catalyst created from the wet impregnation of aluminum on crab shells and plantain peels showed a relatively porous aggregation on the surface compared to the compact surface of the calcined crab shells and the loose fibers of the plantain peels [33]. A similar result was observed when sodium was impregnated on an eggshell precursor, and their SEM morphologies were compared [174]. Another study by Ruatpuia et al. [175] investigated an impregnated iron oxide on banana leaf waste catalyst for the conversion of soybean oil to biodiesel. A comparison of the morphology of the Fe3O4 nanoparticle prepared via co-precipitation (Fig. 12a ) and the impregnated catalyst revealed a reduction in the Fe3O4 particle size and further coverage of the Fe3O4 by carbonates and metal oxides from the banana leaves waste, forming varying-sized horizontally aligned flake-like structures as against the initial non-uniform agglomerates and distribution of the magnetite (Fig. 12b). The prepared catalyst yielded an optimum biodiesel yield of 95.6 % emphasizing the importance of incorporating Fe3O4 with the banana leaf waste. The effect of catalyst impregnation by several active agents has been extensively studied and seen to influence the catalytic behavior and surface properties of precursors significantly. This is evident in the study by Behera et al. [176] when peanut shell biochar was sulfonated to prepare catalysts for biodiesel production. Also, the sulfonation step (–SO3H) was observed to introduce several fissures, crevices, and cracks with irregular and rough edges which improved the porosity of the resulting catalyst (Fig. 13 ). The particle size was also reported to reduce and this was attributed to the breakdown of organic matter and water elimination during dehydration [112]. The sulfonated catalyst was used to prepare biodiesel from algal oil with a yield of 94.91 % under optimized reaction conditions. In another study, a biocatalyst was prepared from insect shells, and the study compared the raw calcined shell (biochar) with the activated biochar and phosphotungstic acid (PTA)-impregnated biochar [155]. The SEM results clearly showed how the activation of the catalyst with ZnCl2 improved the surface area and porosity of the biochar, which was evident in the larger number of discrete pores and their size distribution. This was also reflected in the improved biodiesel yield of 93.87 % under optimized reaction conditions. The reduced pore surfaces on the HPA-impregnated catalyst as seen from the SEM images were taken as an indication of the success of the impregnation with PTA on the biomass support. Similar results were obtained when a ZnCl2-activated banana trunk was also sulfonated using sulfuric acid to produce an acidic catalyst for the transesterification of lipids from C. vulgaris [112]. The SEM result exhibited a loose, porous, and regular morphology, which the authors attributed to the elimination of water molecules during dehydration. The wet impregnation method was used to prepare CaO and SrO catalysts using a rice husk precursor for biodiesel production [119]. The field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images of the pristine rice husk catalyst showed dense and irregular surface morphology. However, impregnation with CaO and SrO revealed a more porous structure, although with a non-uniform surface, indicating the presence of Ca and SrO oxides. The catalyst morphology and uniformity increased with an increase in calcination temperature till optimal (800 °C for CaO and 900 °C for SrO), after which sintering occurred, which enlarged the particle size and resulted in a densely packed surface [177]. The SrO catalyst, however, had a better particle uniformity and size, which is recommended for better catalytic activity, and this was demonstrated in the improved biodiesel yield of 89.97 %. The calcination-hydration-dehydration method has also been reported to produce catalysts with better catalytic activity than the single calcination method. The introduction and subsequent removal of water molecules break down the hydroxides formed during the hydration process and create a more regular, porous, and homogenized structure for the catalyst, which improves its catalytic ability [178]. When a CaO catalyst was prepared from eggshells, the effect of the hydration-dehydration step on the calcined catalyst was explored, and the morphology was evaluated by SEM [111]. As previously observed with calcined catalyst, there was an agglomeration of a varied-shaped (rod-like) structure on the surface of the calcined catalyst, which changed to a honey-comb shape on hydration and dehydration, attributed to the liberation of water molecules from the Ca(OH)2 formed by hydration which contributed to the high biodiesel yield of 94 % obtained under optimized conditions (Fig. 14 ). This was also noted when LiOH blocked waste-tires activated carbon pores [157]. This liberation freed up pore spaces, making it more porous, homogenized, and catalytically more active. This phenomenon was further seen when a nano-CaO catalyst was prepared from eggshells by Ahmad et al. [179]. The calcination of eggshells showed a smooth spherical surface with an irregular morphology, which changed the morphology into a porous agglomerated structure by hydration and dehydration. In a different study, the sol-gel method was used to prepare a mixed metal oxide catalyst from the Croton macrostachyus leaf [180]. This preparation technique was shown to increase surface porosity as the spherical-shaped particles were very small and extremely aggregated. These agglomerations uniquely exposed the poly-crystalline properties of the metal-oxides on the catalyst surface. Post-preparation calcination further reduced the particle size of the catalyst, possibly due to the cell-wall breakage during the sol-gel preparation. In this section, the reviewed works have shown that synthesis methods play a significant role in determining the morphology of heterogeneous catalysts, which in turn has a direct impact on their performance in biodiesel production. The use of techniques such as calcination, impregnation, hydration-dehydration, sulfonation, and activation with agents like ZnCl2 can enhance catalyst porosity and surface area, leading to improved catalytic activity. Calcination, for example, breaks down organic matter, resulting in a more porous structure with increased active surface sites. Impregnation with metals or metallic oxides, such as Fe3O4 on banana leaves or CaO and SrO on rice husk, improves particle regularity and distribution, further optimizing catalytic behavior. The critical analysis of these synthesis methods emphasizes that optimizing catalyst morphology through these techniques directly correlates with higher biodiesel yields, highlighting the important role of controlled morphological tuning in catalyst design. Table 9 shows a summary of some of the studies reviewed in this section. 4.4 Effect on metal dispersion Metal dispersion refers to the arrangement or distribution of active sites, typically metals and their oxides, on the surface of catalyst supports. In the context of heterogeneous catalysis for biodiesel production, effective metal distribution is important because it enhances the catalyst's activity by optimizing the contact between reactants and the active sites [181]. This improved interaction leads to more efficient catalytic processes and higher yields of biodiesel. Metal dispersion is usually influenced by the surface properties of the support, such as porosity, surface area, interaction with the metal, phase transformation, and the synthesis technique [182]. Common and widely used methods to optimize metal dispersion on heterogeneous catalyst supports are preparation of the support material by calcination (or reduction), activation methods to create more pores and porous surfaces for adhesion to the support, wet or incipient impregnation catalyst methods [183]. This section reviews existing studies that examine the impact of various preparation methods on the metal dispersion of catalysts, as determined by different characterization techniques. Synthetic heterogeneous catalysts have been prepared via several methods, such as the co-precipitation method, physical mixing, wet-impregnation method, and sol-gel method, and the effects of these methods have been evaluated on the dispersion of metals. For instance, a vanadium-functionalized catalyst was prepared from pristine calcium oxide using physical mixing, wet-impregnation, and co-precipitation methods and denoted as V2O5 CaO, V2O5.CaO, and V2O5/CaO respectively [184]. The precursor used to prepare the vanadia was NH4V2O5, while the co-precipitation method required Na2CO3 to precipitate the catalyst from the solution, after which the samples from all three methods were calcined. The effects of these catalyst synthesis methods on the metal dispersion were evaluated using the XRD patterns and the temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) results. The different formulation derived from the three methods did not exhibit the diffraction pattern of the metal oxide V2O5 within its diffraction profile. In the case of the Ca-based catalyst variations (V2O5 CaO, V2O5.CaO, and V2O5/CaO), the characteristic peaks of the metal oxide V2O5 were not observed, potentially attributable to the lower V2O5 concentration within the catalyst. This is indicative of a significant interaction between the precursor and the metal surface and an excellent dispersion on the catalyst surface [185]. A similar observation was also reported by Gao et al. [186] for TiO2-supported Mo catalysts prepared using the wet impregnation method who obtained a biodiesel yield of 97.42 % which was attributed to the Mo oxide species being present on the catalyst's surface in a well-distributed manner. The use of special acoustic dispersion techniques can be combined with conventional catalyst preparation methods to improve the metal dispersion on catalyst surfaces. For instance, sono-dispersion was used in combination with the wet-impregnation method to prepare a highly active catalyst material from an Mobil composition of matter No 41 (MCM-41) precursor [187]. Silicon and zirconium metals were both impregnated on the catalyst at varying Si/Zr ratios before Ca was both dispersed and impregnated on it using a sonochemical technique. The effect of the impregnation and dispersion were evaluated using the XRD and FESEM tests. XRD patterns (Fig. 15a ) showed that the sonochemical method enhanced the dispersion of Ca on the catalyst surface which was confirmed by FESEM images (Fig. 15b). A biodiesel yield of 88.5 % was obtained when the catalyst was used for the transesterification of waste cooking oil in contrast with the 83.7 % obtained for the catalyst prepared via the impregnation process alone. The sonicated catalyst did not show a significant loss of efficiency after five cycles of consecutive use. Similar observations were reported when calcium was dispersed on an Al-MCM-41 catalyst [188], and CaO and ZrO2, were dispersed on a kaolin catalyst support [189], both using ultrasound techniques. In another study, two zirconium-based catalysts were prepared via the co-precipitation and Pechini sol-gel methods by Afsharizadeh and Mohsennia [190]. The dispersion of strontium and copper oxides on the support (ZrO) was studied using the FESEM images. They concluded that the co-precipitation method translated to an improved metallic particle mono-dispersion than the Pechini method owing to the presence of more agglomerations in the latter. The presence of slight homogeneous CuO dispersion in the co-precipitation-prepared samples also reduced the agglomerations found on the ZrO2 CuO catalyst in comparison with the ZrO-SrO2 samples that showed far more agglomerations (Fig. 16 ), and this was also reflected in the higher biodiesel yield of 87 % and 86 % when ZrO2 CuO and ZrO-SrO2 were used for the transesterification of waste cooking oil. For biomass-based catalysis, the most common catalyst preparation method that studies the impact on metal dispersion is the wetness and incipient impregnation methods. Most studies that developed biodiesel catalysts from waste biomass lack sufficient details on the impact of the synthesis method on metal dispersions. However, the work of Sulaiman et al. [191] on the wet impregnation of Ni, Zn, and Cu oxides on eggshell-derived CaO is one of the few papers that discussed this. In the study, different ratios of Zn, Ni, and Cu—that is, 10 % to 30 %—were loaded onto the eggshell precursor and were calcined at 700, 800, and 900 °C for 5 h. The 10 % impregnations for the Ni, Zn, and Cu resulted in the best biodiesel yields of 97.30 %, 96.19 %, and 96.38 %, respectively, with the yields steadily decreasing as the metal-oxide loadings increased. This result was particularly attributed to the high dispersion of metals on the catalyst surface. In a similar study, CaO and SrO were impregnated on a rice husk-based catalyst at different ratios of CaO and SrO (10 % to 30 %) to rice husk (SiO2) and then calcined at temperatures of 700 to 900 °C [119]. The study attributed the higher biodiesel yield of 89.97 % from the optimally selected catalyst (10 % SrO at 900 °C) to improved dispersion of metal oxides (active sites) on the catalyst surface, as opposed to the other catalyst (10 % CaO at 800 °C), which produced 83.09 %. The absence of agglomerations was also interpreted from the FESEM image as a direct indication of suitable metal dispersion in a CaO/nano-crystal cellulose/polyvinyl alcohol catalyst matrix derived from egg and coconut shells, respectively [192]. In a separate study, simple calcination and physical mixing methods were used to prepare a CaO catalyst from golden snail shells and a K2O catalyst from banana peels [171]. The SEM images, which were used to evaluate the impact of the preparation method on the prepared catalyst, revealed a smaller particle size when compared to the calcined CaO alone. The study attributed these results to the high dispersion of K2O on the CaO catalyst surface. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) results have also been used to confirm the adequate dispersion of CaO nanoparticles using the calcination-hydration-dehydration catalysis techniques in the conversion of Hydnocarpus wightiana oil and dairy scum to biodiesel [193]. In summary, a major disadvantage of a large catalyst surface area is agglomeration, which leads to clustering instead of the more advantageous metal dispersion, an emerging criterion for higher catalytic activities. This challenge is particularly pronounced with nanoparticles. Careful application of metal dispersion techniques can drastically reduce agglomeration. The studies reviewed in this section as summarized in Table 10 , have shown that optimizing the concentration of dopant during wet impregnation facilitates optimal metal dispersion and consequently enhances catalytic activity. However, there is a paucity of literature dedicated to discussing efficient metal dispersion and the impact of treatment methods on metal dispersion for biomass-based heterogeneous catalysts, unlike the extensive research available for synthetic-based catalysts. To establish the viability of biomass-based catalysts as replacements for synthetic ones, further exploration of special metal dispersion techniques, such as the use of acoustic waves, is needed for waste-derived catalyst systems. 4.5 Effect on chemical composition and reactivity To optimize the efficiency of a catalyst, its chemical composition and reactivity must be effectively assessed. In this section, various catalyst preparation techniques and their effects on the properties of the catalysts used for transesterification reactions will be reviewed and compared. Afsharizadeh and Mohsennia [190] utilized the Pechini sol-gel and co-precipitation methods to synthesize ZrO2-SrO2 and ZrO2 CuO mixed oxides catalysts to catalyze biodiesel production from waste cooking oil and corn oil. They reported that optimal performance was achieved at a similar molar ratio of 2/1 for Zr/Sr and Zr/Cu, a reaction temperature of 120 °C, a methanol/oil molar ratio of 10/1, and a reaction time of 3 h. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis confirmed the presence of Zr, Sr, Cu, and O, with the Pechini-derived catalysts containing residual carbon from ethylene glycol. The co-precipitation method resulted in catalysts with higher metallic content, indicating superior catalytic efficiency for biodiesel production. In a similar work, Dehghani and Haghighi [187] explored the potential for enhancing MCM-41 catalysts by incorporating Zr and varying the Si/Zr molar ratio. The researchers then loaded the catalysts with calcium using conventional impregnation and sono-dispersion. The results of EDX analysis showed effective dispersion of calcium in the sonicated samples. XRD confirmed the formation of MCM-41 and CaO, while FESEM images revealed nanoscale particle sizes (Fig. 17 ). The sonicated Ca/ZM-U (Si/Zr = 10) displayed superior reusability and catalytic performance for biodiesel production, demonstrating the efficacy of ultrasound irradiation in improving the dispersion of the active phase. In another study, Asuquo et al. [194] undertook direct calcination of kola nut pod husks to produce a solid catalyst for biodiesel production. In the course of their study, samples of calcined and uncalcined fermented kola nut husks were compared using the X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis to determine the effect of calcination on the metal oxide and elemental contents of the developed catalyst. The analysis revealed that the elemental and metal oxide compositions such as calcium, potassium, iron, and zinc amongst others present in the calcined samples were significantly higher than those in the original feedstock and this the authors attributed to the effectiveness of the calcination process. The presence of these elements and metal oxides helped to increase the effectiveness of the catalyst in biodiesel production. Ahmad et al. [179] prepared a heterogeneous nano-CaO catalyst from waste eggshells through a calcination-hydration-dehydration process. The EDX spectra indicated the elemental content, which included Ca, O, Si, Mg, K, and Fe and this was reported to contribute to the reactivity of the catalyst which gave the optimal biodiesel yield of 93.44 % achieved using 2.06 % catalyst, 180 min, and 60 °C, demonstrating the catalyst's effectiveness in biodiesel production. Mohebolkhames et al. [195] studied the transesterification of sunflower oil using waste salmon fishbone as a heterogeneous catalyst. The catalyst was synthesized via calcination and wet impregnation method using potassium hydroxide. Calcination was done to convert the calcium present in the waste fish bone to its oxide form, while wet impregnation was carried out to effectively distribute potassium on the CaO catalyst support. To determine the effect of the wet impregnation technique on the elemental composition of the synthesized catalyst, an EDS study was carried out and results obtained showed the presence of potassium in high concentrations amongst other elements like oxygen, calcium, and carbon. This was suggestive of the efficiency of the wet impregnation technique in successfully distributing potassium onto the catalyst support. Saikia et al. [196] developed a heterogeneous catalyst from Musa glauca stem through direct calcination for biodiesel production from soybean oil. They compared the efficiency of calcined and burnt Musa glauca catalysts. Transesterification results showed a biodiesel yield of up to 96.7 % with the calcined catalyst, compared to 57.1 % with the burnt catalyst. XRF analysis revealed higher concentrations of potassium and calcium in the calcined sample. Moreover, all elements (K, Ca, Si, Mg, P, Na, Mn, Fe, and Al) in the calcined catalyst were present as oxides due to the high calcination temperature. The mixed metal oxides in the calcined catalyst, which have higher catalytic ability than single metal oxides, likely contributed to its superior performance. According to Bousba et al. [197], a NaOH/CoFe2O4 magnetic nano-catalyst was developed using wet impregnation and co-precipitation techniques for biodiesel production from waste cooking oil. The CoFe2O4 nanoparticles were synthesized via co-precipitation, and magnetic properties were introduced with NaOH via wet impregnation. The EDX analysis demonstrated that the Fe/Co atomic ratio in the nanoparticles was comparable to the nominal ratio, indicating the efficiency of co-precipitation. The presence of sodium on the NaOH/CoFe2O4 catalyst confirmed the success of wet impregnation. The results of the study suggested that wet impregnation effectively enhanced the catalytic activity of the magnetic nano-catalyst, making it suitable for biodiesel production. Chutia and Phukan [198] produced a magnetic solid catalyst consisting of ash from jute leaves and Fe3O4 via calcination and subsequent co-precipitation method. The synthesized catalyst was employed in the transesterification of soybean and jatropha oils. In the course of their study, a comparison was done between calcined and uncalcined jute magnetic catalysts based on their basicity via the EDX test. The results obtained from this analysis showed that the basicity of the calcined catalyst was higher than that of the uncalcined sample and this was evident in the elevated levels of calcium and potassium present. The authors attributed this to the effectiveness of the calcination process that was carried out on the calcined sample. Aworanti et al. [199] in their study developed an economical solid catalyst from waste cow teeth for the production of biodiesel from waste frying vegetable oil. The solid catalyst was synthesized using the calcination-hydration-dehydration technique. To determine the concentration of elements and metal oxides present in the developed catalyst, XRF analysis was carried out. Results of this analysis showed the presence of calcium oxide, phosphorus pentoxide, magnesium oxide, strontium oxide, zinc oxide, manganese (II) oxide, and zirconium oxide, which are recognized as essential in improving the catalytic activity of the catalyst. The properties of the catalyst based on the calcined and uncalcined cow teeth were also compared and the results showed that the calcined sample had a higher percentage of calcium oxide. This higher calcium oxide content may be attributed to the thermal degradation of the hydroxyapatite (Ca₅(PO₄)₃(OH)) of the teeth during the calcination process employed. In the development of heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production, the chemical composition, reactivity, and overall performance of these catalysts have been shown to be influenced by preparation techniques such as co-precipitation, calcination, wet impregnation, and sono-dispersion as seen in the studies summarized in Table 11 . For instance, co-precipitation can be used to balance the metal content in mixed oxides like ZrO2-SrO2 and ZrO2 CuO, while calcination can increase the concentration of important metal oxides in waste-derived catalysts like cow teeth and jute leaves, improving catalytic activity. Wet impregnation methods, like those used in NaOH/CoFe2O4 catalysts, can effectively incorporate active phases, further enhancing performance. Thus, by optimizing these synthesis methods, it is possible to fabricate catalysts with optimal elemental composition, which is important for high biodiesel yields. Additionally, the integration of ultrasound irradiation in sono-dispersion techniques can improve the dispersion of active phases, enhancing reusability and overall efficiency. In summary, the choice of synthesis method directly impacts the elemental composition and reactivity of catalysts, which in turn determines their effectiveness in biodiesel production. 4.6 Effect on thermal stability It is essential to examine the thermal stability, the ideal calcination temperature, and the behavior of a catalyst during decomposition since these considerations can influence the catalytic activity of the catalyst [200]. In this regard, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) is typically carried out. Chutia and Phukan [198] produced a magnetic solid catalyst consisting of ash from jute leaves and Fe3O4 via calcination and subsequent co-precipitation method. In the course of their study, calcined and uncalcined jute magnetic catalysts were compared based on their thermal stability using TGA. The results revealed that the uncalcined jute magnetic catalyst (UMC) had a greater percentage of weight loss compared with the calcined catalyst (CMC). The resulted indicated that the calcination process reduced the composition of volatile matter present in the catalyst sample leading to an increase in the stability of the catalyst (Fig. 18 ). In another study, Fiala et al. [116] developed a solid catalyst from the solid residue of durian peels via the wet impregnation method using potassium hydroxide to produce a yeast-based biodiesel. TGA analysis was carried out on the synthesized catalyst to determine its rate of decomposition and thermal stability. The results showed that the potassium-doped catalyst (DPS-K) was stable in the temperature range of ∼150–250 °C (Fig. 19 ), which was desirable as it encompasses the typical transesterification reaction temperature range (60 and 85 °C). Majamo et al. [201] developed a catalyst from sugarcane bagasse and doped with FeSO4·7H2O. TGA analysis was carried out to determine the thermal stability of the synthesized catalyst. Results obtained show the developed catalyst was stable at high temperatures (at about 700 °C). Mohebolkhames et al. [195] studied the production of biodiesel from sunflower oil using waste salmon fish bone impregnated with potassium hydroxide as a heterogeneous catalyst. To determine the thermal stability of the catalyst, TGA was carried out and the results obtained show that the catalyst was thermally stable at high temperatures above 799.85 °C. This was considered by the authors as an indication of the stability of the catalyst. Ashine et al. [113] developed a solid catalyst from chicken eggshells using the calcination-hydration-dehydration technique for the production of biodiesel from Argemone mexicana oil. TGA was carried out to determine the thermal stability of the developed catalyst. The results obtained showed a maximum weight loss of about 20 % at a temperature range of 400 – 502 °C which was attributed to the decomposition of CaCO3, the removal of CO2, and the conversion of Ca(OH)2 into CaO. The authors further concluded that the calcination-hydration-dehydration technique was effective in increasing the catalytic ability of the developed catalyst during the transesterification reaction. Rahman et al. [202] in their study developed a mixed metal oxide of Zn-CaO via the wet impregnation method from CaCO3 present in chicken eggshells for the transesterification of waste palm oil. TGA was carried out to determine the thermal stability and the optimal calcination temperature of the synthesized catalyst. Results from the analysis showed that the synthesized Zn-CaO was stable up to temperatures above 800 °C as very minimal weight loss was recorded at these temperatures as such the ideal calcination temperature was set at 900 °C. The authors also concluded that temperatures above 800 °C are ideal for the conversion of calcium carbonate to calcium oxide. Akhtar et al. [203] in their study developed a cerium oxide nanocatalyst using Tragacanth gum via the wet impregnation method for the production of biodiesel from Descurainia sophia (L.) seed oil. TGA was carried out to investigate the thermal stability of the synthesized catalyst. Results from the analysis show that the catalyst was thermally stable up to 600 °C as seen from the minimal weight loss recorded at this temperature. The important role of synthesis methods in enhancing the thermal stability of heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production is emphasized by the reviewed studies. Thermogravimetric analysis reveals that techniques such as wet impregnation, calcination, and calcination-hydration-dehydration have a significant impact on catalyst stability and performance. Catalysts prepared via calcination often exhibit improved thermal stability and reduced volatile matter content, while wet impregnation can enhance the dispersion of active components, leading to higher stability and catalytic efficiency. The collective findings of these studies indicate that optimal synthesis methods not only improve thermal stability but also enhance catalytic activity, thereby increasing the effectiveness of catalysts in biodiesel production. 5 Challenges in heterogeneous catalyst synthesis To achieve optimal catalytic performance, a highly effective heterogeneous catalyst should possess favorable pore size, surface area, and active site characteristics while also possessing minimal risk of leaching. From an economic standpoint, a suitable solid catalyst should also be non-toxic, non-corrosive, safe to handle, easily separable, readily available, highly reusable, and cost-effective. While previous studies have reported positive outcomes, the effectiveness of the catalyst can be directly impacted by problems encountered during catalyst preparation, which can vary depending on the method used [204]. For example, some common challenges associated with the use of sol-gel methods for synthesizing heterogeneous catalysts include cracking and deformation of the catalyst during preparation, dispersion of the active phase of the catalytic material, and decreased pore size and specific surface area due to calcination and drying [205]. The calcination step is important in the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts due to its influence on the structural properties and catalytic activities. However, the high temperatures required for the synthesis of catalysts increase energy consumption and costs [36]. Moreover, the use of the direct calcination method to prepare a catalyst from agricultural wastes has been reported to impose additional costs and demands on the catalyst generation process [38]. Researchers have identified issues in the control of particle size and morphology in the context of sol-gel synthesis [206,207]. Variations in pH, temperature, and aging time during the sol-gel process can significantly impact the final catalyst properties [208]. Thus, achieving consistent catalyst performance and reproducible results can be challenging due to the sensitivity of the sol-gel method to these parameters. For instance, Samin et al. [209] prepared Cr-Ti mixed oxide catalysts through the sol-gel method for the transesterification of cooking palm oil to produce biodiesel. They reported that varying the calcination time from 1 h to 5 h led to a decrease in pore size, attributed to sintering at high calcination temperatures. Zheng et al. [210] also reported the impact of calcination on catalyst synthesis during the synthesis of a hierarchical calcium-based catalyst, CaO(S), for no-glycerol biodiesel production. The CaO(S) was synthesized using calcium nitrate-ethanol-citric acid as a precursor and rape pollen as a biotemplate via the sol–gel-biotemplate method. The TPD analysis showed that the basicity of the catalyst reduced from 5.9 mmol/g at 700 °C to 3.89 mmol/g at 800 °C due to surface sintering, which also negatively impacted the specific surface area. Kunde and Yadav [211] reported problems such as cracking and deformation during the synthesis of mesoporous metal-aluminate films via the sol-gel method. The formation of crack-free films was influenced by heat during the drying process and calcination. According to Woranuch et al. [212], the calcination temperature employed in the direct calcination process has a significant impact on the activity of CaO catalysts. They discovered that elevating the calcination temperature beyond 900 °C caused a decrease in biodiesel yield which was attributed to the sintering of the particles. This observation is similar to that reported in a recent study by Iskandar et al. [131] who noted that the use of high calcination temperatures negatively impacted the effectiveness of the catalyst as a result of particle agglomeration. Physical mixing, while a straightforward approach, often results in the production of catalysts with unfavorable properties. For instance, Tsubaki et al. [213] prepared a bifunctional catalyst, Cr2O3/H-ZSM-5, by physically mixing the precursors. The authors reported that the physical mixing method for synthesizing bifunctional or multifunctional catalysts typically leads to the disordered intermediate transfer phenomenon, which is caused by the open and unrestricted reaction field, thereby hindering the selectivity of the targeted product. Mota et al. [103] provided insight into the physical mixing method for catalyst synthesis. They stated that this approach does not allow for precise control of the size and distribution of the active metal and acid sites, resulting in catalysts that have an open structure. In heterogeneous catalyst synthesis, achieving consistent and uniform dispersion of the active phase is a major challenge. Another challenge is the sintering effect, particularly for catalysts with high active agent loading [136]. For instance, the wet impregnation method, which is effective in incorporating active metals into the support matrix, often results in uneven distribution and aggregation of the active species. This aggregation can potentially reduce the overall efficiency of the catalyst. Mohebolkhames et al. [195] reported challenges with the incorporation of potassium hydroxide into the waste salmon fish bone using wet impregnation, which affected the catalytic performance. Also, Mehrabadi et al. [214] reported that the impregnation method does not typically produce catalysts with a high level of metal dispersion and this was attributed to the limited interaction between the support and the doping agent. They also noted that another weakness of this method is the difficulty in controlling the size of metal particles apart from when the support is porous with a narrow particle size distribution. Although the co-precipitation method is effective for producing mixed oxide catalysts, Bellardita et al. [215], reported challenges when differences in solubility between components can lead to successive precipitations. These precipitations can create concentration gradients in the final catalyst resulting in poor mixing of the components. However, this may be less important if the components form distinct, insoluble species. In the catalyst preparation by calcination-hydration-dehydration using waste-derived precursors, Ao et al. [104] revealed that catalysts rapidly hydrate to Ca(OH)₂ and carbonate to CaCO₃ when exposed to water and CO₂, leading to quick deactivation. Reactivation requires outgassing at high temperatures (550–700 °C), further adding to energy costs. Furthermore, to enhance activity, stability, and recyclability, additional modifications like doping with metals or supporting on another metal oxide are often required, adding complexity to the preparation process. The authors emphasized further that active sites on the catalyst can become cloaked by adsorbed intermediates or byproducts such as monoglycerides, diglycerides, and glycerol, leading to deactivation. The scalability of synthesis methods also poses a challenge. While effective at a laboratory scale, the methods reviewed often face significant challenges when scaled up for industrial production. These methods require precise control over preparation conditions, such as pH, temperature, and concentration, which can be difficult to maintain consistently on a larger scale. For instance, Awogbemi et al. [38] studied trends in the utilization of agricultural wastes as heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production. They reported the challenges associated with the use of calcination-hydration-dehydration methods for catalyst preparation, noting that different waste materials may require specific adjustments to the preparation conditions to achieve the desired catalytic properties. This need for material-specific optimization can limit the generalizability of the method. In addition, the process is time-intensive, involving stages like refluxing for several hours and multiple high-temperature treatments. This can be a barrier to scaling up the process for industrial applications. Another significant challenge is the thermal stability of the prepared catalysts. Thermal stability is important for maintaining catalytic activity over an extended period of usage and demanding reaction conditions. However, several synthesis methods, such as direct calcination, can lead to the formation of catalysts with poor thermal stability as reported by Chutia and Phukan [198]. For instance, their study of jute-based magnetic catalysts shows that the catalysts exhibited significant weight loss, indicating poor thermal stability. This instability can result in catalyst deactivation over time, necessitating frequent regeneration or replacement, which is not economically feasible. Furthermore, the environmental and economic aspects of the synthesis methods cannot be disregarded. Many traditional methods involve the use of toxic chemicals and solvents, which pose environmental hazards and increase the cost of catalyst production. For instance, the co-precipitation method often employs hazardous reagents, which require careful handling and disposal [216]. Ahmad et al. [179] emphasized the need for greener and more sustainable synthesis approaches, noting that the calcination-hydration-dehydration process used for producing nano-CaO catalysts from waste eggshells, while effective and uses cheap precursors, still relied on high temperatures and energy inputs. In summary, significant progress has been made in developing heterogeneous catalysts from bio-derived precursors for biodiesel production, but several challenges associated with the synthesis methods remain. These challenges include issues related to the uniform dispersion of active components, thermal stability, scalability, environmental and economic impacts, and reproducibility. Addressing these challenges is important for advancing the practical application of these catalysts in industrial biodiesel production. 6 Conclusion and future prospects In conclusion, the methods used in the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts from bio-derived precursors have a significant impact on their structural properties, thermal stability, chemical composition, and overall performance in the production of biodiesel. Different methods, such as physical mixing, calcination, sol-gel, wet impregnation, and co-precipitation, have been thoroughly examined, demonstrating the distinct roles they play in shaping catalyst characteristics. Physical mixing, while both cost-effective and simple, often leads to weak metal-support interactions that can affect the performance of the catalyst. In contrast, calcination improves the physicochemical properties and active site dispersion, resulting in improved catalytic activity and reusability. The sequential calcination-hydration-dehydration method is an advancement of calcination and leads to enhanced catalytic performance and stability. While wet impregnation and co-precipitation methods allow for the synthesis of highly active and stable catalysts, it is essential to precisely control the synthesis conditions to prevent particle agglomeration. The sol-gel method, known for producing high-purity catalysts, effectively integrates various precursors to form robust catalytic systems. The findings presented herein emphasize the role of synthesis methods in optimizing catalyst properties and their subsequent performance in biodiesel production. The reviewed studies also highlight several challenges associated with the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts from bio-derived precursors. Issues such as achieving a uniform particle size distribution, controlling phase composition, and maintaining high surface area remain relevant. Additionally, the environmental and economic aspects of these synthesis methods warrant careful consideration. Developing green synthesis techniques that minimize energy consumption and reduce the use of hazardous chemicals is essential for sustainable biodiesel production. The scalability of these methods also poses a significant challenge, since laboratory-scale successes must be translated to industrial-scale applications without compromising efficiency and cost-effectiveness. Overall, the insights gained from this review emphasize the need for a comprehensive approach to catalyst design, taking into account both the synthesis methods and their practical implications in biodiesel production. Looking ahead, future research should focus on several key areas to advance the field of heterogeneous catalysis for biodiesel production. For instance, there is a need for the exploration of novel bio-derived precursors. Although agricultural wastes such as eggshells, fish bones, and plant residues have shown potential, many other organic materials remain unexplored. These materials could possess unique structural and compositional properties, which might lead to the development of more efficient catalysts. Furthermore, the integration of advanced characterization techniques, such as in situ spectroscopy and super-resolution microscopy, will provide deeper insights into the structural evolution and active site dynamics of catalysts during synthesis and reaction processes. This understanding will facilitate the design of catalysts with properties tailored for specific precursors and reaction conditions. Moreover, there is a need to develop and optimize green synthesis methods that align with the principles of sustainability and the circular economy. Techniques such as supercritical fluid extraction, microwave-assisted synthesis, ultrasound-assisted synthesis, and solvent-free methods show promise in reducing environmental impact while maintaining or enhancing catalytic performance. Additionally, future research should also focus on improving the regeneration and recyclability of catalysts to improve their economic viability and reduce waste generation. The development of robust catalysts that maintain high activity and selectivity over multiple reaction cycles is important for the commercial viability of biodiesel production processes. Additionally, interdisciplinary collaboration will be essential in addressing the multifaceted challenges in this field. Finally, the combination of expertise from materials science, chemical engineering, environmental science, and renewable energy will greatly foster innovative solutions and accelerate the transition from laboratory research to industrial implementation. coredata.dc:description: The over-reliance on fossil fuels has led to significant environmental and climatic challenges, emphasizing the urgent need for sustainable energy alternatives. Biodiesel, which is traditionally produced through the transesterification of vegetable oils and animal fats, provides a low-carbon alternative to fossil fuels. However, for catalytic systems, the efficiency of biodiesel synthesis is significantly dependent on the nature of the catalysts used. Conventional homogeneous catalysts, although effective, face challenges such as high energy consumption, soap formation, non-recoverability, and corrosion issues. In contrast, heterogeneous catalysts, especially those derived from biogenic waste, offer cost, reusability, and environmental impact advantages. This review provides a comprehensive examination of the synthesis methods and performance of heterogeneous catalysts derived from waste materials for biodiesel production, representing an elucidation of the role of synthesis methods on the properties of these catalysts. Understanding this relationship is important for optimizing biodiesel production efficiency as global efforts intensify to transition away from fossil fuels. This review analyzes the properties of these catalysts, such as surface area, pore structure, morphology, metal dispersion, chemical composition, and thermal stability, using fit-for-purpose characterization techniques. By focusing on the synthesis-property-performance nexus, this review highlights the importance of selecting and optimizing synthesis methods to achieve high-performance catalysts for efficient biodiesel production. The review also addresses challenges in heterogeneous catalyst synthesis, providing a balanced perspective on the current state of the art. Importantly, this work establishes a new framework for understanding and optimizing bio-derived catalyst synthesis, paving the way for more efficient and sustainable biodiesel production methods. This review contributes new knowledge to the field of renewable energy, aligning with global sustainability goals.
